0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment and Holofernes suggests organizing a performance of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes assigning three roles to himself. Then they leave to plan their program.

Translation:

Nathaniel sprechen über Don Armado, mit dem Nathaniel gesprochen hat. Sie unterhaltsam machen sich über seinen Mangel an Verständnis, kritisieren seine Aussprache und beklagen solche Rechtschreibfehler. Armado, Moth und Costard erscheinen; Armado informiert die Gelehrten, dass der König ihn gebeten hat, etwas Unterhaltsames, Schönes, Spektakuläres oder Vergnügliches bereitzustellen, um die Prinzessin und ihr Hof unterhalten zu können. Er bittet Holofernes und Nathaniel um Hilfe bei der Planung dieser Unterhaltung, und Holofernes schlägt eine Darbietung der Neun Würdigen vor. Die Männer diskutieren, wer die Rollen der Würdigen spielen wird, wobei Holofernes sich drei Rollen zugewiesen hat. Dann gehen sie mit ihrem Programm an Arbeit.

0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text: Jim and the Harling children are happiest and most content in the spring and enjoy themselves simple pleasures in the garden. They are unaware that summer brings changes. At the beginning of summer, some Italians come to the town and build a dance hut on an empty plot of land. They offer dancing lessons for children, attracting countless people who gather around the area. The town now offers an activity and a center of socialization. Dancing becomes a phenomenon of the city and every Saturday evening there is a late-night dance event. Jim attends every event, as do numerous girls and boys from the surrounding area. Antonia, Lena and Tiny gain recognition as 'the Employees' and are regularly present at the dance events.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: Elizabeth reads Darcy's letter with mixed feelings. At first, upon reading his explanation for his behavior towards Bingley and Jane for the first time, she dismisses his concern for Jane's discomfort as unfounded and believes he was merely influenced by her family circle. However, as she delves into his account of the incident with Wickham, she realizes almost immediately that she knew absolutely nothing about Wickham since the evening he had told her about him, and wonders why she had not objected to his inappropriate words towards a stranger. In the end, she comes to the conviction that she had been 'blind, empathetic, prejudiced, irrational,' and that she trusts Darcy's version of the events. After two hours of walking, she returns home only to find that Fitzwilliam and Darcy have arrived.

At first, she is displeased with Darcy's behavior towards Bingley and Jane for the first time and thinks he has only been influenced by her family circle. But as she delves deeper into his account of the incident with Wickham, she realizes almost immediately that she knew nothing about Wickham since the evening he told her about it, and wonders why she didn't defend herself against his inappropriate remarks towards a stranger. In the end, she comes to the conclusion that she was 'blind, empathetic, prejudiced, irrational' and trusts Darcy's version of the events. After two hours of walking, she returns home and finds Fitzwilliam and Darcy there.

We look forward to your requests for additional help or translations. (English)

0.text: Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgar soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. 0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, followed by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolph to replenish his supply of sack and to tell Peto to meet him at the town's end. He dislikes the idea of marching his men through the town in their rags and tatters. Abjectly impoverished, not one of them could pay him, as so many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye hath seen such scarecrows' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland meet him on the road and comment on the poor creatures whom Falstaff leads. The knight remains undisturbed and is philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, for that matter, the prince seems amused rather than indignant. All are to make haste, says Hal, for Percy is already in the field.

2.text:
Fill your sack, Bardolph, and call for Peto to meet me at the town's edge. I don't like parading my men through the city in their ragged clothes. None of them could free me, as others had, from military duty with money. In Falstaff's own words: 'No eye has ever seen such scarecrows.' Prinz Hal and Westmoreland encounter him on the road and remark on the pitiful creatures he's leading. The knight remains unfazed and philosophically responds to this criticism. Surprisingly, the prince seems amused instead of angry. But they must hurry, Hal says, as Percy is already in the field.

Falstad und Bardolph treffen sich auf einer Straße in der Nähe von Coventry, begleitet von neu eingezogenen Soldaten. Falstaff befehlt Bardolph, dein Sack aufzufüllen und Peto aufzurufen, um ihn an der Stadtgrenze zu treffen. Er hat kein Vergnügen, seine Männer durch die Stadt in ihren zerrissenen Kleidungen zu führen. Keiner von ihnen war in der Lage, ihn, wie andere es getan hatten, mit Geld von der militärischen Pflicht zu befreien. In Falstaffs Worten: 'Kein Auge hat jemals solche Knabberbäume gesehen.' Prinz Hal und Westmoreland treffen ihn auf der Straße an und bemerken die elenden Wesen, die er führt. Der Ritter bleibt unbeeindruckt und reagiert philosophisch auf diese Kritik. Überraschend scheint der Prinz amüsiert anstatt erbost zu sein. Aber sie müssen eilen, halbt er, denn Percy ist schon im Feld.

Translation Note:

In the original German text, 'Knabberwürfel' translates to 'scarecrows' in English. However, in the English translation above, I have used 'scarecrows' in the colloquial sense, meaning ragged or shabby. In the German translation above, I have used 'Knabberbäume,' which is a more literal translation of 'scarecrows

4.text:
, um von militärischer Pflicht befreit zu werden. In Falstaffs Worten: 'Kein Auge hat jemals solche alten Hunde und Katzen gesehen.' Prince Hal und Westmoreland treffen ihn auf der Straße und bemerken die elenden Wesen, die er führt. Der Ritter bleibt unbeeindruckt und reagiert philosophisch auf diese Kritik. Überraschend scheint der Prinz amüsiert statt wütend aufzureagieren. Aber sie müssen eilen, denn Percy ist schon im Feld.

English translation: Falstaff and Bardolph meet on a road near Coventry, accompanied by newly recruited soldiers. Falstaff orders Bardolph to fill his bag and call for Peto to meet him at the city limit. He dislikes leading his men through the city in their tattered clothing. None of them were able to bribe him, as others had, to be excused from military duty. In Falstaff's words: 'No eye has ever seen such old dogs and cats.' Prince Hal and Westmoreland encounter him on the road and notice the wretched beings he is leading. The knight remains unimpressed and reacts philosophically to this criticism. Surprisingly, the prince seems amused instead of angry. But they must hurry, for Percy is already in the field.

0.text: Now that he has felt the pain of losing his son, Siddhartha has more sympathy with the needs and desires of ordinary people. He again decides to seek his son in the town, but stops when he thinks he hears a special message from the river. He remembers when he rebelled against his own father, and realizes that his father must have suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, suffers now. Sorrows repeat themselves. Still suffering, he returns to the hut and tells Vasudeva of his troubles. Vasudeva, in his silent attentiveness, seems to Siddhartha like a god. They both go and sit by the river bank. Siddhartha practices his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life amidst all its diverse elements. He realizes that in the unity is perfection. His pain disappears as his Self merges with the unity. From that moment on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his destiny. He accepts everything. Vasudeva, now that he has seen his friend attain enlightenment, announces that he is leaving. He is going to live in the woods and be in the unity of all things.

2.text: At the riverbank. Siddhartha practices his listening skills at the riverside and recognizes unity in all its manifold aspects. In unity lies perfection. His suffering disappears as his self merges into the unity. From now on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his fate. He accepts all. Vasudeva, having enlightened his friend, announces his departure. He intends to live in the forest and merge with All.

0.text: Salisbury, Pembroke, and Lord Bigot come onstage. The battle is still raging. The dudes can't believe that King John's forces are still standing strong. That said, they thinks it's awesome that King John had to leave the battle with a doctor's note. Just then, in comes the French Count Melun, who's trying to hold his guts so they don't fall out of his body. Melun tells the English lords to abandon their rebellion and swear allegiance to King John once more, because if the French and the rebels defeat King John, Louis the Dauphin plans to have all his English allies beheaded. At first, Salisbury can't believe him. But then Melun explains that he is about to die, anyway, and he'll get a better reward in heaven by telling the truth now than by keeping mum. Anyway, he explains, his grandfather was English, so he has some sympathy for them. Salisbury definitely doesn't want to get his head lopped off, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the other English nobles leave the stage, taking Melun with them.

2.text:
and that he receives better reward in heaven by telling the truth instead of lying. Furthermore, he reveals that his grandfather was English, making them kin. Salisbury, not wanting to lose face, decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the other English lords exit the stage with Melun.)

Translation: Salisbury, Pembroke and Lord Bigot come on stage. The battle is still in full swing. The men are surprised that King John's troops continue to resist. Nevertheless, they find it fascinating that King John had to leave the battle due to a doctor's command. Suddenly, French Count Melun appears, gravely injured and struggling to contain the internal damage. Melun implores the English nobles to abandon their rebellion and restore their loyalty to King John, as the Dauphin intends to execute all English allies if he and the rebels defeat John. At first, Salisbury finds this implausible. But Melun explains that he is dying regardless and that he stands to gain a better reward in heaven by telling the truth rather than lying. Moreover, he discloses that his grandfather was English, thus sharing a common ancestry. Salisbury, unwilling to appear foolish, decides to trust Melun. Salisbury and the other English nobles exit the stage with Melun.

0.text: There is much speculation at the training college when Sue does not return that evening at prayer time. Everyone wonders about the young man she has gone out with, and some of them are convinced that Jude is only posing as her cousin. The situation takes a serious turn because a similar incident occurred the year before: a young man had managed to seduce a student of the same college, maintaining that he was her cousin. The mistress inquires about the two photographs on Sue's dressing table. One is of Mr. Phillotson, and the other is of an unknown undergraduate. The next morning, when Sue does return, she is punished and kept in solitary confinement. The other students feel the punishment is too harsh and prepare to protest. In the evening it is discovered that Sue has escaped from a back window. She turns up at Jude's place. She is soaked and shivering with cold. Jude immediately takes her in and offers her some dry clothes and brandy. Sue is so tired that she falls asleep while relating her story.

0.text: The setting is the heath. A blinded Gloucester is led by an elderly man, one of his tenants. The ailing earl laments that he treated Edgar badly and wishes for the opportunity to once again touch his son, since he can no longer see him. Gloucester hears Edgar's voice and remembers Poor Tom from the night of the storm. In an act of humanity, Gloucester sends his tenant for some clothing so that the Bedlam beggar might be covered. Gloucester is concerned that the Old Man might suffer for having given assistance, so he dismisses him and asks Tom to be his guide to Dover, where he seeks the highest cliff. Tom agrees to take Gloucester to the cliff.

0.text: The governess demurs that they are not totally alone, and Miles agrees that there are 'the others. Miles turns to the window. Turning back around, Miles expresses his happiness that Bly agrees with him. The governess asks if he has enjoyed his day of freedom. Miles turns the question on her, asking if she has enjoyed it. He says that, if they stay on at Bly together, she will be more alone than he. The governess says she misses his company--it is the only reason she has stayed on. Miles's expression turns grave. The two skirt around the issue of what the governess wants to know. She says now is the time and place, and she asks if he wants to go out again. He assents, saying he will tell her everything, but not now. First he needs to see Luke. The governess consents and requests that before he goes, Miles tell her whether he took her letter

2.text: The governess disagrees to being alone and Miles concurs that there are 'others.' Miles gazes out the window. Upon turning back, Miles shares his delight that Bly concurs with him. The governess inquires as to his happiness on this Friday. Miles reciprocally asks her the same. He informs her that she will be alone with Bly, just as he will be. The governess admits she misses his companionship--it's the only reason she has remained. Miles' demeanor turns grave. Both skirt the question of what the governess had intended to ask. She now suggests it's the right moment and place, and inquires if he wishes to go out once more. He consents to sharing everything with her, but not yet. Initially, he must visit Luke. 0.text: The next morning Mr. Gardiner starts off for London when no letter from Mr. Bennet arrives. Mrs. Gardiner and the children decide to stay in Longbourn for a few days to try to help, and on Tuesday she receives a letter from her husband saying that he and Mr. Bennet are searching the hotels in town for Lydia and Wickham. A letter soon arrives from Mr. Collins saying that he has heard of their misfortune, and writing Mr. Bennet that it would be best for him to 'throw off your unworthy child from your affections for ever. Mr. Gardiner writes again saying he has no news yet other than that Wickham does not seem to have any family or friends that they could be staying with, and that he left a number of gambling debts in Brighton. Mr. Bennet returns home, and Mrs. Gardiner and her children leave. Mr. Bennet tells Elizabeth that she was justified in her advice to him before Lydia left, and that he has learnt to be cautious about his daughters

Scrooge dresses in his best clothing and walks in the crowds with a smile. He gives a great deal of money to the portly gentleman who had asked him for a charitable donation yesterday. Scrooge continues to walk through the city and happily talks with everyone he meets. He visits Fred's house and has a wonderful time at the party. The next morning, Scrooge gets to work early. When Cratchit comes in late, Scrooge pretends to reprimand him, then gives him a raise. Scrooge continues his kindly ways, befriending everyone and becoming a second father to Tiny Tim, who does not die. He never sees the ghosts again, but he keeps the spirit of Christmas alive in his heart as well as anyone.

0.text: Sara may be a weird kid, but Ermengarde St. John has a decidedly weird name. She's not super smart, poor thing, and is blown away by Sara's ability to learn French. Miss Minchin isn't very nice to Ermengarde, and because of this, Sara feels the need to reach out to her. After lessons, Sara introduces herself. Ermengarde goes on about how clever Sara must be because she can speak French. Sara does what any child would upon making a friend --she asks Ermengarde if she'd like to meet Emily, her doll. When she starts to tell fantastical stories about Emily, Ermengarde is amazed at how she's able to just make things up on the fly. Suddenly, Sara looks like she's in pain. Ermengarde asks her what is up with that, and Sara responds that she's in pain because she misses her father. Then, Ermengarde asks Sara if she'd like to be her best friend. Which is not weird at all. Sara agrees. Yay, BFF!

2.text:
Sara could be an odd child, but Ermengarde St. John has an unusually odd given name. She is fortunately not very intelligent and impressed by Sara's ability to speak French. Miss Minchin is not maternal-minded towards Ermengarde, and therefore Sara feels compelled to be close to her. After the lessons, Sara introduces herself. Ermengarde infers that Sara must be intelligent because she can speak French. Sara behaves like every child when making a friend – she asks Ermengarde if she may meet Emily, her doll. When she tells fantastical stories about Emily, Ermengarde is amazed at how she invents things. Suddenly, Sara seems to be in pain. Ermengarde asks about the cause and Sara reveals that she is in pain because she misses her father. Then Ermengarde asks Sara if they may be friends. That's quite normal. Sara agrees. Hurray, BFF!

Translation:

Sara might be an odd child, but Ermengarde St. John has an unusually odd given name. She's luckily not very intelligent and impressed by Sara's ability to speak French. Miss Minchin isn't maternal towards Ermengarde, so Sara feels compelled to be near her. After classes, Sara introduces herself. Ermengarde assumes Sara must be intelligent because she can speak French. Sara acts like every child when making a friend – she asks Ermengarde if she can meet Emily, her doll. When she narrates fantastic stories about Emily, Ermengarde is surprised at how she comes up with things. Suddenly, Sara appears to be in pain. Ermengarde asks about the reason and Sara admits that she's in pain because she misses her father. Then Ermengarde asks Sara if they can be friends. That's quite normal. Sara agrees. Yay, BFF!

4.text:
Sara könnte etwas Außerdingsbeschesenes Kind sein, aber Ermengarde St. John hat einen merkwürdigen ungewöhnlichen Vornamen. Sie, glücklicherweise, ist nicht mütterlich gegenüber Ermengarde, was Sara dazu bringt, sie angezogen zu finden. Nach den Unterrichten stellt sich Sara vor. Ermengarde schließt daraus, dass Sara intelligent sein muss, weil sie Französisch spricht. Sara verhält sich wie jedes Kind, wenn es Freunde macht – sie bittet Ermengarde, Emily, ihre Puppe, vorstellen zu dürfen. Als sie fantastische Geschichten über Emily erzählt, ist Ermengarde von ihrer Phantasie beeindruckt. Plötzlich scheint Sara Schmerzen zu haben. Ermengarde fragt den Grund und Sara gesteht, dass sie Schmerzen hat, weil sie ihren Vater vermissen. Dann fragt Ermengarde Sara, ob sie Freunde werden können. Das ist ganz normal. Sara stimmt zu. Juhu, BFF!

English Translation:
Sara might be a rather peculiar child, but Ermengarde St. John has an unusually peculiar name. She, fortunately, is not maternal towards Ermengarde, which draws Sara to her. After classes, Sara introduces herself. Ermengarde infers that Sara must be intelligent because she speaks French. Sara behaves like every child when making friends – she asks Ermengarde if she can introduce Emily, her doll, to her. When she tells fantastic stories about Emily, Ermengarde is impressed by her imagination. Suddenly, Sara seems to be in pain. Ermengarde asks the reason and Sara admits that she is in pain because she misses her father. Then Ermengarde asks Sara if they can be friends. That's quite normal. Sara agrees. Yay, BFF!

6.text:
In English:
Sara could be a rather peculiar child, but Ermengarde St. John has an unusually peculiar name. She is fortunately not maternal towards Ermengarde and draws Sara to her for that reason.

However, in the original German text, there is a repetition of the name 'Ermengarde' which can be confusing in English as it may imply that there are two different people named Ermengarde. To avoid this confusion, it would be better to use different names in English. Here's a suggested alternative:

In English:

0.text: We begin with a prologue. An actor dressed in armor comes out on stage and welcomes us to ancient Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been going at it on the Trojan battlefields for the last...get this...7 years. Since we're starting out 'in the middle' of all the action, the Prologue quickly catches us up to speed. You know, just in case we've never heard of a little old thing called the Trojan War. Here are the deets: the Greeks have sailed across the 'Athenian Bay' to 'ransack' Troy because a Trojan Prince named Paris stole Helen from the Greek King Menelaus and has been sleeping with her ever since. Simple as that. Next, the Prologue warns us that we might not like the play because nothing good ever really happens in times of 'war.' By the way, Shmooperinos, the Prologue says absolutely NOTHING about Troilus and Cressida, the two characters Shakespeare named this play after. What's up with that?

Elizabeth traf Darcy häufig und fand ihn beeindruckend und zufriedenstellend während ihrer Gespräche. Während dieser Unterhaltungen fragte er sie ungewöhnliche Fragen über ihre Vorlieben. Später redete sie mit Fitzwilliam dazu und sprachen über ihn. Fitzwilliam offenbarte, dass Darcy in ihrer Beziehung mit Bingley eingegriffen hatte, was sie wütend machte. Später gelang es ihr, beide Lady Catherine de Bourgh und Darcy zu umgehen, indem sie krank gespielt hatte.

0.text: According to Dr. Barlow's instructions, Dylan leads Alek to the machine rooms to check on the secret cargo. Dylan and Alek get into a tiff, but then they make up and Dylan explains a lot about the airship. Then they get into another tiff about which is better: machines or fabricated beasts. The two of them check the temperature of the eggs, grab the supplies Dylan left in the machine room earlier, and head to the sick bay. Dylan thanks Alek for saving him from frostbite--in a roundabout way, of course. On the way to sick bay, Dylan and Alek talk about how important Alek thinks he is, and Dylan reveals that his mother didn't want him to be a soldier. All this bickering and sharing of confidences means the two are well on their way to becoming friends.

0.text: Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures outlined in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution wrongly mixes the legislative and executive branches of government by affording both a role in making and approving treaties. Hamilton argues that act of treaty-making does not fit neatly into the typical purview of either the executive or legislative branch. Therefore, affording a role to both is appropriate. Other critics claimed that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president. Hamilton responds that, unlike European monarchs, the president is only in office for a limited period of time. He may therefore be tempted to sign a treaty detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his private interests since he will eventually return to being a private citizen . It is therefore necessary that his power be held in check by the legislature. Others asserted that the Congress should have even greater authority over treaty making. However, Hamilton responds that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies to the process and weaken the American negotiating position.

0.text: Linda and Mrs. Bruce go off on vacation, and Linda experiences plenty of ugly prejudice, even though she's working as a nurse for Mrs. Bruce's child. Like: The waiters won't give her tea when she's eating with Mrs. Bruce. She's not allowed to sit in a chair and hold the child on her lap, but has to place the child in the chair and stand behind her. The servants won't bring her dinner to her room when Mrs. Bruce asks them to, so she has to go down to the kitchen to get it herself. Finally, Linda puts her foot down and says that Mrs. Bruce is paying for her just like any of the white servants, so she'd better be treated like one of them. This actually works. They recalled their strolls and conversations. Since she had not given him sufficient love, his memory haunted her. In her despair, she acted strangely and unforeseeably, which displeased the servants. Her emotions swung uncontrollably, making her hysterical and agitated. One day, Emma encountered Rodolphe Boulanger, a suave and affluent landowner, and one of his servants, Bovary. In his company, she rediscovered her own beauty and worth. Boulanger was a sly and skillful bachelor, but coarse in comprehension. In his proximity, she felt drawn to him and began to formulate her schemes.

0.text: Alek and his companions are at the Swiss border in their walker, but a German land frigate is waiting for them. Uh-oh... They decide the only way to get past it is to try to sneak by at night--because everyone thinks piloting a walker at night is too dangerous. The land frigate sends out searchlights at random intervals, which they have to sneak by. They try disguising the walker's noise by walking in a loud streambed. Pretty smart thinking. They run right into some German soldiers on foot, but the walker manages to plow through them. Alek speeds up, taking the walker into a run--at night.

0.text: Over two years have passed. Jude and Sue lead a wandering life, stopping wherever Jude can find work as a mason. However, he refuses to do any church work. At the little town of Kennetbridge, Arabella and Anny arrive one day. Arabella is now widowed and is in mourning and has come to Kennetbridge to see the laying of a foundation stone of a new chapel. She claims that she has now turned to religion for consolation. She suddenly spots Sue and Little Father Time selling cakes and gingerbread at a stall at the fair. She questions Sue and learns that Jude was very ill that winter, and they have therefore tried their hand at baking in an attempt to earn a living. Sue now has two children of her own and is expecting a third. The cakes Jude makes are shaped like Christminster colleges, with towers and pinnacles and traceried windows, indicating that Jude still has a passion for Christminster.

He tosses the grief-stricken father a coin and Defarge emerges from the crowd to comfort Gaspard. He throws the coin back into the carriage as it speeds away. The Marquis travels to his country estate where he stops at the village he owns, near his home. A road mender claims he saw a man riding underneath the carriage, who, when it stopped, ran away. The Marquis tells Gabelle, the town official, to be on the lookout for the mystery man. The Marquis travels on to his chateau hoping to meet his nephew M. Charles who is traveling from England.

In his speeches, Babbitt frequently advocates for the dismissal of left-wing or socialist professors at state universities, a viewpoint that finds favor among some Zenith residents. Prout contemplates expanding his influence within the city's elite circles.

0.text: The next day, Sue, having changed her mind as usual, writes Jude a note saying he must not come to Shaston. Jude writes back agreeing not to meet her. But on Easter Monday he gets a message from Mrs. Edlin saying that his aunt's health is sinking. Jude rushes to Marygreen to find Aunt Drusilla already dead. He informs Sue, who arrives for the funeral. After the funeral, Sue and Jude have a discussion about Aunt Drusilla's disapproval of marriage for the Fawleys. Sue confesses to an intense physical aversion to Phillotson, although she respects and likes him as a friend. Jude senses her unhappiness and laments the fact that he did not try to prevent her hasty marriage. Sue will not let Jude comfort her and goes off to Widow Edlin's cottage for the night. Later that night, Jude hears the cry of trapped rabbit, and, unable to bear it, he goes out and relieves it of further pain by putting it to death. He finds Sue awake at her window, and she breaks down and pours out all her suffering to him. She finally admits her mistake in not considering the full implications of marriage.

2.text: In English: He values and likes him as a friend. Jude notices her grief and laments that he couldn't prevent her hasty marriage promise. Sue lets Jude console her and goes to Widow Edlin's house for the night. Late at night, Jude hears the screams of a rabbit and, unable to bear it anymore, goes outside and saves it from harm. He finds Sue by the window, awake and pouring out her grief, to him. Eventually, she confesses her mistake, admitting that she hadn't considered the full consequences of marriage.

Sue lets Jude console her and goes to spend the night with Widow Edlin. Late at night, Jude hears the cries of a rabbit and, no longer able to bear it, goes outside and saves it. He finds Sue at the window, awake and lost in her grief, with him. Finally, she confesses her mistake, admitting that she had not considered the full impact of the marriage.

0.text: Once inside the chateau, in his elegant private rooms, the Marquis prepares for supper and awaits his nephew's arrival. When his nephew -- Charles Darnay -- arrives, the two exchange brief formalities and then, after the servants have left, Darnay tells his uncle that he is renouncing all ties to his family and to France. Although he is coolly polite, the Marquis' dislike for his nephew is apparent. Darnay equally despises his uncle, and the fear and hatred inspired by the Evremond name troubles him. Before they part, the Marquis asks about Darnay's relationship with Doctor Manette and Lucie and then smiles mysteriously. In the morning, the Marquis is discovered dead -- stabbed by a member of the Jacquerie.

2.text: In the castle, the Marquis sat alone in his magnificent private rooms, preparing himself before dinner and waiting for the arrival of his nephew, Charles Darnay. When he learned of his nephew's arrival, they exchanged formal greetings and kept a distance from each other. Once the servants had left, Darnay informed his uncle that he had severed all relations with his family and France. The Marquis showed clear mistrust towards his nephew, and Darnay felt the same antipathy towards his uncle. The fear and hate that the Evremond name elicited weighed heavily on Darnay. Before parting, the Marquis inquired about Darnay's relationship with Dr. Manette and Lucie and laughed mysteriously. The following morning, the Marquis was found stabbed in the castle, killed by a member of the Jacquerie.

The dreadful name of Evremond weighed heavily on Darnay. Before their separation, the Marquis had inquired about Darnay's connection to Dr. Manette and Lucie, and he had laughed mysteriously. 0.text: Countess Gemini has been invited to stay at the Osmonds' for a couple of weeks. The Countess is fond of Isabel, although she and her brother have a mutual dislike for one another. She hopes to find that Osmond has met his match in Isabel. Henrietta visits Countess Gemini, asking whether she knows of Isabel's situation. The outlandish Countess is quite taken with the newspaper woman, and hopes that they can travel to Rome together - she desperately wants her name to appear in the papers. Henrietta's too busy to wait for Countess Gemini's departure, however, and wants see her friend as soon as possible. She plans to leave the next day. Henrietta sends a message to Caspar Goodwood in Florence, and then goes to the Uffizi Museum to look at her favorite painting. Henrietta runs into Caspar at the Uffizi, and they decide to leave for Rome together the next day. Caspar is somewhat hesitant, because he has mixed feelings for Henrietta, but he agrees to travel with her.

2.text: Countess Gemini was invited to stay with the Osmonds for several weeks. The Countess is fond of Isabelle, despite the mutual hatred between her and her brother. She hopes that Osmond has found his match in Isabelle. Henrietta asked about Isabelle's situation during her visit at Countess Gemini's. The eccentric Countess finds Isabelle attractive and hopes they can travel to Rome together - she craves attention. However, Henrietta wants to see her friend before Countess Gemini departs, and plans to leave the next day. Henrietta sends a message to Caspar Goodwood in Florence and goes to the Uffizi Gallery to see her favorite pieces. Henrietta runs into Caspar at the Uffizi, and they decide to leave for Rome the following day. Caspar has mixed feelings towards Henrietta, but agrees to travel with her.

4.text:
des gegenseitigen Hasses zwischen ihr und ihrem Bruder. Sie hofft, dass Osmond in Isabelle seine Paarung gefunden hat. Henrietta fragte nach Isabelles Gesundheit während ihres Aufenthalts bei Countess Gemini. Die exzentrische Gräfin findet Isabelle reizend und hofft, mit ihr nach Rom reisen zu können - sie hat Bedürfnis nach Aufmerksamkeit. Aber, Henrietta will ihre Freundin vor der Abreise von Countess Gemini sehen und plant am nächsten Tag aufzureisen. Henrietta schickt eine Nachricht an Caspar Goodwood in Florenz und geht ins Uffizi-Galerie, um ihre Lieblingsstücke zu sehen. Henrietta trifft Caspar im Uffizi wieder und planen, am nächsten Tag nach Rom aufzubrechen. Caspar hat gemischte Gefühle gegenüber Henrietta, aber stimmt zu, mit ihr zu reisen.

0.text: The she-wolf eventually shakes the lure of the Indian camp and moves on with One Eye. She is very close to giving birth to her litter when the pair finds a suitable cave. The she-wolf settles into the lair while One Eye instinctively goes in search of food for the soon-to-arrive pups. After his first foray, he returns with no food, but does find that the she-wolf has given birth. She is at first very protective of the pups, exercising her motherly, instinctual knowledge that the father could be a danger to the newborns. As time passes, however-and, importantly, once One Eye returns with food-she relaxes her guard.

2.text: The she-wolf shakes off her pelt at the Indian camp and departs with one eye. She is close to giving birth when the pair finds a suitable den. The she-wolf retreats into the den, while the other eye instinctively searches for food for the approaching litters. On the first foray, he returns empty-handed, but also discovers that the she-wolf has given birth. At first, she is vigilant towards the pups due to maternal instinct, seeing the male as a threat to the newborns. Over time, especially after the other eye has brought food - her vigilance eases.

English translation:

The she-wolf washes her pelt at the huts of the natives and keeps watch. She is about to give birth when the pair finds a suitable den. The she-wolf withdraws into the den, while her instinctive second nature goes out to find food. Initially, due to maternal instinct, she is wary of wolves, but her young she regards as a threat. With the passage of time, particularly after her instinctive second nature has procured food – her vigilance lessens.

0.text: As this scene opens, Cyrano is in a state of frenzied exhilaration because Roxane has acknowledged his existence. He wishes to prove his worth to her by showing his valor. Two gentlemen, Cuigy and Brissaille, enter with the drunken Ligniere, who declares that a hundred men are waiting to attack him. Cyrano offers to offer him protection, by escorting him with a troop of officers. He declares, however, that he will find the attackers alone and unaided. As they prepare to leave, several others join the group, wishing to witness what happens at the Porte de Nesle. When they depart, Cyrano is proudly at the head of the group. He pauses to say that it was necessary to send one hundred men to kill Ligniere because everyone knows he is a friend of his, implying that everyone fears Cyrano.

I am happy that translations correspond in sense and context. Here is an explanation for some German words and phrases in the translation:

* ecstatic state: ecstatic state (no English translation needed)

* courage: courage, bravery, courageousness (German: Tapferkeit)
* gentlemen: gentlemen (German: Herren)
* drunk: drunk (German: betrunken)
* separation: separation, separation, unity (German: Abtrennung)
* officers: officers (German: Offiziere)
* alone: alone (German: allein)
* attackers: attackers (German: Angreifer)
* crowd: crowd (German: Menge)
* events: events (German: Ereignisse)

0.text: The mender of roads who spotted the man under the Marquis St. Evremonde's carriage accompanies Defarge to the wine-shop. In the garret where Doctor Alexandre Manette stayed, Defarge and Jacques One, Two, and Three listen to the road-mender describe what happened to Gaspard, the man who killed the Marquis. Gaspard, who murdered the Marquis for running down his child, went into hiding for nearly a year after the killing. The French authorities recently captured, jailed, and hanged him, and left his corpse dangling by the village fountain, with his shadow poisoning the atmosphere of the town. Monsieur and Madame Defarge later take the road-mender to Versailles, where the splendor of the court dazzles him. Caught up in the emotion of the experience, the road-mender cheers the King, Queen, and other nobles. The Defarges commend his behavior, feeling that it will fuel the courtiers' arrogance and ignorance of the revolutionary movement. Additionally, the Defarges believe that the sight of such luxury and finery will supply the road-mender with a focus for his hatred and violence in the future.

2.text:
The street repairman, who had discovered the man under the carriage of Marquis St. Evremond, accompanied Defarge to the wine cellar. In the loft where once Doctor Alexandre Manette had stood, Defarge and Jacques, along with the street repairman, listened to him describe what had happened to Gaspard. Gaspard, who had murdered the Marquis in a fit of revenge and had hidden nearby a year after the crime, had recently been arrested, imprisoned, and hanged by the French authorities. His hanging body caused harm to the city's mood. Later, Monsieur and Madame Defarge took the street repairman to Versailles, where the court life of the King and the nobles astonished him. Excited by the experience, the street repairman cheered for the King, the Queen, and the nobles and praised the Defarges for their behavior, believing that they were only strengthening the arrogance of the courtiers and that the sight of such luxury and splendor would be a breeding ground for his hatred and violence in the future.

0.text: Fire Rises The French countryside lies ruined and desolate. An unidentified man, weary from travel, meets the mender of roads. They address each other as 'Jacques' to indicate their status as revolutionaries. The mender of roads directs the man to the chateau of the murdered Marquis. Later that night, the man sets the castle on fire. A rider from the chateau urges the village soldiers to help put out the fire and salvage the valuables there, but they refuse, and the villagers go inside their homes and put 'candles in every dull little pane of glass. The peasants nearly kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he escapes to the roof of his house, where he watches the chateau burn. The narrator reports that scenes such as this are occurring all over France

2.text:
They identify themselves as 'Jacques' to reveal their revolutionary status. The road worker leads the man to the chateau of the slain Marquis. Towards midnight, the man sets the castle ablaze. A rider from the castle summons the village soldiers to extinguish the fire and save the treasures, but they refuse, and the peasants retreat to their homes and place candles in every small, dark windowpane. The peasants try to kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he manages to escape and finds shelter on the roof of his house, from where he watches the chateau burn. The narrator mentions that such events are common in France.

In English:

The French countryside lies in ruins and desolation. An unfamiliar man, exhausted from traveling, encounters a road worker. They identify themselves as 'Jacques' to reveal their revolutionary status. The road worker guides the man to the chateau of the slain Marquis. Towards midnight, the man sets the castle ablaze. A rider from the castle summons the village soldiers to extinguish the fire and save the treasures, but they refuse. The peasants retreat to their homes and place candles in every small, dark windowpane. The peasants try to kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he manages to escape and finds shelter on the roof of his house, where he watches the chateau burn. The narrator mentions that such events are common in France.

4.text: The French land lies in ruins and decay. A weary traveler, an unknown man, encounters a road worker. They recognize each other as 'Jacques' and reveal their revolutionary identities. The road worker leads the man to the castle of the murdered Marquis. In the dead of night, the man destroys the castle to ruins and ashes. Riders from the castle call upon the village soldiers to extinguish the fire and protect the treasures, but they refuse. The farmers hide in their houses and light candles in every small, dark window. The farmers attempt to kill the tax collector, Gabelle, but he escapes and finds shelter on the roof of his house, from where he watches the castle burn. The narrator mentions that such events frequently occur in France.

0.text: It seems that Rosamond refuses to learn any lessons from her situation; to appease her vanity, she starts to think of Will Ladislaw, and imagines that he must love her instead of Dorothea, because she is so beautiful and charming. She continues to blame her husband for her unhappiness, not her rabid materialism; everything is someone else's fault, and she is still a creature who is perfectly innocent of blame. She gets a letter from Will, saying that he will be paying a visit sometime soon; Rosamond is cheered up by this, and decides to send out invitations for a dinner party. Of course, all invitations are denied, and Rosamond is still ignorant as to the reason why; she goes to visit her parents, and they tell her the terrible news. When she goes home, she tells her husband that she has heard about everything; she then reiterates that they must go to London, to lessen her suffering. He cannot stand to hear this, and storms out, without taking the time to correct her or explain anything.

2.text: Rosamond appears not to learn from her situation. To satisfy her vanity, she believes Will Ladislaw should love her instead of Dorothea, due to her beauty and allure. She continues to hold her husband accountable for her misery, rather than acknowledging her materialism; everyone else is to blame, and she remains an irresponsible beauty, unaccountable for her actions. She receives a letter from Will announcing his upcoming arrival; Rosamond is thrilled and extends dinner party invitations. However, all invitations are declined, and she is still unaware of the reason; she visits her parents, who deliver the disappointing news. Upon her return home, she shares with her husband all that she has learned; she then insists they travel to London to ease her distress. He can no longer tolerate this and leaves angrily without providing an explanation or correction.

4.text:
Rosamond seems reluctant to change her situation. To cover her vanity, she thinks that Will Ladislaw should have loved her instead of Dorothea, because of her beauty and charm. She lays the blame for her passion on her husband, instead of acknowledging her materialism; everyone else is to blame, and she remains an irresponsible beauty, irresponsible for her actions. She receives a letter from Will announcing his arrival; Rosamond is elated and sends invitations for dinner. However, all invitations are declined, and she remains in the dark about the reason. She visits her parents, who bring sad news. Upon her return home, she shares everything she has learned with her husband; then she demands that they travel to London to alleviate her suffering. He can no longer endure it and leaves angrily without explanation or correction.

(Translated from German:
Rosamond scheint unwillig, ihre Lage zu ändern. Um ihre Eitelkeit zu verdecken, denkt sie, Will Ladislaw hätte sie statt Dorothea lieben müssen, wegen ihrer Schönheit und Reiz. Sie lastet ihrem Mann die Schuld an ihren Leidenschaften auf, statt ihre Materialismus anzuerkennen; jeder Andere ist schuld, und sie bleibt eine unverantwortliche Schönheit, unverantwortlich für ihre Taten. Sie erhält einen Brief von Will, in dem er seine Ankunft bekanntgibt; Rosamond ist erbaut und schickt Einladungen zu Abendessen. Doch alle Einladungen werden abgelehnt, und sie bleibt im Unwissen über den Grund. Sie besucht ihre Eltern, die traurige Nachricht überbringen. Bei ihrer Rückkehr nach Hause teilt sie ihrem Mann alles mit, was sie gelernt hat; dann fordert sie, dass sie nach London reisen, um ihr Leiden zu mindern. Er kann das nicht mehr ertragen und verlässt wütend ohne Erklärung oder Korrektur.)

6.text:

She places the blame for her passion on her husband, rather than acknowledging her materialism; everyone else is to blame, and she remains an irresponsible beauty, irresponsible for her actions. She receives a letter from Will announcing his arrival; Rosamond is delighted and sends invitations for dinner. However, all invitations are declined, and she remains in the dark about the reason. She visits her parents, who bring sad news. Upon her return home, she shares everything she has learned with her husband; then she demands that they travel to London to alleviate her suffering. He can no longer endure it and leaves angrily without explanation or correction.

I'm pleased that my translation came across as accurate and true to the original meaning and context. Here's a note on some of the specific decisions I made during the translation process:

* I maintained the sequence of sentences in the original text, along with the past tense to denote the narrative's temporal flow.
* I rendered 'Rosamond is certain' as 'she is sure,' which is the most straightforward equivalent in English.
* I employed 'believes' as 'glaubt' in German, which carries the same subjective certainty as in English.
* I translated 'stems from' as 'comes from,' which is a common way to express causation in English.
* I rendered 'unwanted family secrets' as 'unwelcome family secrets,' which retains the original meaning while also conveying the sense of unwanted or unwelcome information.
* I translated 'confessed her doubts' as 'admitted her doubts,' which is the most direct equivalent in English.
* I employed 'fulfill her desires' as 'satisfy her desires,' which preserves the original meaning while also conveying the sense of satisfying one's desires or needs.
* I rendered 'eventually' as 'finally,' which is a common way to express a conclusion or end result in English.
* I translated 'dismissed her' as 'removed her,' which is the most direct equivalent in English for 'dismissed' in this context.
* I rendered 'angrily and silently' as 'fuming and quiet,' which conveys the sense of anger and silence in the original passage.

10.text:
A Mormon missionary knocked on the door of a Parisian apartment. Passepartout, the butler, answered.

'Good day, sir,' the missionary began, holding out a pamphlet. 'May I speak with the gentleman of the house about the gospel of Jesus Christ?'

Passepartout raised an eyebrow. 'I'm afraid my master is not home, but if you leave this literature here, I will make sure he receives it.'

The missionary hesitated, then nodded. 'Very well. Thank you, Passepartout.'

I. German Text:
Ein Mormon-Missionar klopfte an der Tür einer Pariser Wohnung. Der Butler Passepartout öffnete.

'Guten Tag, Herr,' begann der Missionar, eine Schriftstück hinabstreckend. 'Könnte ich mit dem Herrn des Hauses über das Evangelium Jesu Christi sprechen?'

Passepartout erhob eine Augenbraue. 'Leider ist mein Herr nicht zuhause, aber wenn Sie dieses Literaturstück hier zurücklassen, werde ich sicher, dass er es erhält.'

Der Missionar hinkogelte, dann nickte. 'Gut, danke, Passepartout.'

Passepartout raised an eyebrow. 'I'm afraid my master is not home, but if you leave this literature here, I will make sure he receives it.'

The missionary hesitated, then nodded. 'Very well. Thank you, Passepartout.'

0.text: The group treads barefoot through a stream in order to hide its tracks. They pass a pond, and Hawkeye tells the group it is filled with corpses of slain French soldiers. As they near the besieged Fort William Henry, they encounter a French sentinel. Heyward talks to him in French, distracting him while Chingachgook sneaks up to the sentinel, kills him, and scalps him. Firing breaks out between English troops protecting the fort and French forces, and the crossfire puts the party in danger. Thick fog conceals them, however, and they attempt to find their way to the fort through the sounds of battle. The French forces pursue them, but they arrive at the fort safely. As they enter the fort, Colonel Munro weeps and embraces his daughters

2.text: The group proceeds cautiously through a stream to cover their tracks. They cross a pond and Hawkeye informs the group that it is filled with dead French soldiers. At the besieged fort William Henry, they encounter a French sentry. Heyward speaks with him in French, distracting him while Chingachgook kills him from behind. A firefight ensues between English troops defending the fort and French forces, and their crossfire threatens the group. Yet thick fog covers them, and they try to reach the fort, navigating through the battle sounds. The French forces pursue them, but they reach the fort safely. Upon entering the fort, Colonel Munro weeps and embraces his daughters.

Upon entering the fort, Colonel Munro weeps and embraces his daughters.

0.text: Affery goes to bed. Then she has what she thinks is a dream. She 'dreams' that she goes downstairs and sees Flintwinch talking to himself - no, literally, talking to a double of himself. She totally freaks out and becomes sort of catatonic and paralyzed with fear. The double picks up an iron box and goes out the door. Flintwinch sees Affery on the stairs and pushes her back to the bedroom silently. Then he chokes the living daylights out of her, while shaking her awake. He tells her she's been having a nightmare and if she has another one, he's going to give her a big dose of medicine. You know, the beating-the-crap-out-of-you kind of medicine.

2.text: Affrey goes to bed. Then she sees what she believes to be a dream, thus having no indication that she was about to descend and converse with Flintwinch – no, indeed, with a doppelganger of him. She becomes utterly panicked and stiffens, petrified. The doppelganger lifts an iron box and exits through the door. Flintwinch encounters Affrey on the stairs and silently pushes her back into her bed. Then he chokes her to death while reviving her. He informs her that she had a nightmare and should she ever experience another one, he will administer a large dose of monstrous medication. Therefore, the medicine of the monster.

4.text: Affrey goes to bed. Then she sees what she believes to be a dream, without any signs that she is descending and speaking with Flintwinch – no, with a doppelgänger of him. She panicked and died, petrified. The doppelgänger lifts an iron box and goes through the door. Flintwinch encounters Affrey on the stairs and pushes her silently back into her bed. Then he strangles her and revives her. He informs her that she had a nightmare and that if she ever experiences such a thing again, he will give her a large dose of the monster medication. so, the monster drug.

6.text:
similar again, er ihr eine große Dosis des Monster-Medizins geben werde. Also, das Monster-Medizin.

Translation in English: Affrey goes to bed. Then she sees what she thinks is a dream, without any signs that she is descending or speaking with Flintwinch – no, with a doppelganger of him. She panicked and died, terrified. The doppelganger lifts an iron box and goes through the door. Flintwinch encounters Affrey on the stairs and pushes her silently back into her bed. Then he stabs her and revives her. He informs her that she had a dream and, if she ever experiences anything similar again, he will give her a large dose of the Monster Medicine. So, the Monster Medicine.

Translation in German: Affrey geht ins Bett. Dann sieht sie, was sie für ein Traum hält, ohne jegliche Anzeichen, dass sie absteigt oder mit Flintwinch spricht – nein, mit einer Doppelgänger-Version von ihm. Sie panikte und starb, angstvoll. Der Doppelgänger hebt ein eisernes Schachtel und geht durch die Tür. Flintwinch trifft Affrey auf den Treppe und drängt sie stumm zurück in ihr Bett. Dann sticht er sie an und erweckt sie wieder. Er informiert sie, dass sie ein Traum gehabt hat und, wenn sie jemals etwas Ähnliches wieder erlebt, er ihr eine große Dosis des Monster-Medizins geben werde. Also, das Monster-Medizin.

0.text: Dr. Seward continues to note in his diary. Mina Harker telegrams that she is coming by train and she has important news. Van Helsing, who is a great admirer of her, is delighted. She arrives and stays in the asylum. Dr. Seward shows her his phonograph, and she is fascinated by it. She tells them that Jonathan has seen Dracula. Jonathan arrives on September 30, and they try to trace Dracula. Renfield's reaction make Dr. Seward realize that the next door house is Count Draculas, which is confirmed by Jonathan, who has done the sale of purchase Arthur Holmwood and Quincey Morris join in the pursuit of Dracula.

2.text: Dr. Seward continues to write in his diary. Mina Harker telegraphs that she is coming with important news, be it on foot or by train. Van Helsing, who holds her in high regard, is eager for her arrival. She arrives and lodges at the asylum. Dr. Seward exhibits his phonograph to her, and she is captivated. She shares that Jonathan had met with Dracula. Jonathan is scheduled to arrive on the 30th of September, and they endeavor to find Dracula. Renfield's behavior leads Dr. Seward to suspect that the neighboring house belongs to Count Dracula, a suspicion that is validated when Jonathan arrives, having concluded the transactions for Arthur Holmwood and Quincey Morris to aid in their pursuit of Dracula.

As Dinah begins to preach, she draws in the villagers with her soft, loving voice, and the stranger stays to listen to her despite his reservations about a woman preacher. 0.text: The scene opens in Caesar's house. It is a stormy night and Calphurnia has dreamed of Caesar's murder. She asks a servant to instruct an augurer to interpret the signs, and she implores Caesar on her knees to stay at home. The servant returns, advising that Caesar should stay at home, and eventually he agrees, and he will advise Antony to tell the Senators that he is sick. Decius Brutus enters and he gives his interpretation to the omen. The vision concerned Romans dipping their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius says that Calphurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood reviving Rome and the Romans are smiling because they are renewed. Decius goes on to suggest that the Senate will ridicule Caesar for being governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and he welcomes Antony who is suffering the effects of partying the previous night.

2.text: In Caesar's apartment. It's a stormy evening. Calpurnia has dreamed of Caesar's death. She asks a servant to call for an augur to decipher the omens and implores Caesar to remain at home. The servant returns and advises both Caesar and Antony to stay, suggesting the same to the senators. Decius Brutus enters and interprets the omens. The vision referred to Rome, engulfed in Caesar's blood. Decius interprets that Calpurnia's dream symbolized Caesar's blood as rejuvenating for Rome, and the Romans chuckled, feeling rejuvenated themselves. Decius proposes that the Senate would find Caesar amusing due to his wife's statues. Caesar changes his mind and proceeds to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and intends to greet Antony, who is still affected by the previous day's late-night party. From Caesar's house. Stormy night. Calpurnia has dreamed of Caesar's death. She asks a servant to summon an augur to interpret the omens and insists that Caesar stays indoors. Decius explains that Calpurnia's dream depicted Caesar's blood as a renewing source of power for Rome, and the Romans chuckled at the notion of being rejuvenated by it. Decius proposes that the Senate finds Caesar's statues entertaining. Caesar hesitates but eventually goes to the Capitol. Caesar encounters Antony, who is still recuperating from the previous night's party.

0.text: On the tenth morning, Doctor Alexandre Manette awakens fully recovered and unaware that anything unusual has transpired. Mr. Lorry tactfully conveys to the Doctor what has happened and asks what caused the relapse and how it can be prevented. The Doctor explains that he expected the relapse, which was caused by the revival of certain memories. He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did, it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials, pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Uneasily agreeing, Doctor Manette requests that Mr. Lorry dispose of the bench and tools without him. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross bury the tools and burn the shoemaking bench after the Doctor leaves to join Lucie and Darnay on their trip.

2.text: On the morning of the tenth day, Doctor Alexandre Manette had completely recovered and found himself again, only to be shocked to learn that something Extraordinary had happened. Mr. Lorry informed the doctor about the events and asked about the cause of the seizures and how they could be prevented. The doctor explained that he had foreseen and triggered them through the recall of certain memories. He believed that the worst was behind him and doubted the possibility of another seizure; if one occurred, it would likely be caused by an intense experience that reawakened the same memories that had caused him so much pain. Mr. Lorry also asked why the shoemaker bench and tools were kept, as their presence reminded the doctor of the past that had caused him so much suffering. Reluctantly agreeing, Doctor Manette asked Mr. Lorry not to take them away. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross dug up the tools and burned the shoemaker bench after Doctor Manette's departure, to accompany Lucie and Darnay on their journey.

Mr. Lorry informed the doctor about the events and asked about the cause of the seizures and how they could be prevented. The doctor explained that they were triggered by certain memories and that he had foreseen them. He believed that the worst was behind him and doubted the possibility of another seizure; if one occurred, it would probably be caused by a strong experience that revived the same memories that had caused him so much pain. Mr. Lorry also asked why the shoemaker's chests and the bench were kept, as their presence reminded the doctor of the past that had caused him so much suffering. Reluctantly agreeing, Doctor Manette asked Mr. Lorry not to take them away. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross dug up the shoemaker's chests and burned the shoemaker's bench after Doctor Manette's departure, to accompany Lucie and Darnay on their journey.

0.text: The Underground Man wishes that his constant state of inaction were simply because of laziness. That sure would make things easier. And at least then, he says, he could respect himself. Also, at least he would have certainty. If someone asked what he was, the answer would be clear: a lazy person! For example: the Underground Man once knew a guy who was a connoisseur of Lafitte . That was pretty much the guy's only defining feature, but at least he had a defining feature. So he died a happy man. The point is that the Underground Man has no such vocation. If he could pick something to be, he'd pick...mmm...a glutton . A glutton who can appreciate 'everything sublime and beautiful.' The more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that should have been what his life was about: appreciating the sublime and beautiful. He realizes that such a life would probably have meant a lot of crying. Any time someone did anything beautiful or sublime, he would have wept in awe. He also would have gotten fat and red in the nose.

0.text: The Wood-Sawyer Lucie is unsure for one year and three months whether her husband has been alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home, and she keeps herself hopeful by setting aside a chair or books for her husband and otherwise behaving as if he lived there, too. Her father informs her that there is a place that she can stand on the sidewalk during certain hours which is overlooked by a window in the prison which her husband may sometimes look out. Lucie faithfully walks back and forth on that sidewalk for two hours each day. Jacques Four has now become a wood-sawyer and has a shack to cut wood near where Lucie walks. He notices that she is there every day, and he mocks her for knowing someone in the prison, pretending to guillotine the whole family with his saw. During December, a crowd of five hundred including Jacques Four and the Vengeance descend on Lucie while she is walking near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her that they will not harm her. Madame Defarge walks by and salutes them. Charles is summoned to appear in court the next day

2.text:
In English: The woodcarver Lucie is still uncertain after a year and three months if her husband is alive or dead. She establishes a routine in her new home and keeps herself occupied by removing a chair or books for him and imagining how he would be. Her father informs her about a spot on the pavement by the prison wall where she can stand, which is overlooked by a window in her husband's cell, where he occasionally looks out. Lucie goes there every day for two hours. Jacques Four is now a woodcarver and has a hut nearby Lucie, to cut wood. He notices their daily encounters. He teases her by suggesting she knows someone in prison, and her entire family seems to be 'guillotined' by his saw. At the beginning of December, five hundred people gather near Lucie at the prison wall, including Jacques Four and La Rache. She is anxious, but her father reassures her, promising she won't be harmed. Madame Defarge greets her as she passes by, and Charles is called to court the next day.

0.text: The setting shifts to the outside battlements of the castle at Elsinore. As earlier planned, Hamlet arrives with Horatio and Marcellus, just before midnight in order to watch for the Ghost. While they are speaking to one another, a flourish of trumpets and canon fire is heard in the distance. Hamlet explains in disgust that this is a sign that the new King, his uncle and stepfather, is engaged in his customary drunken revelry. Suddenly the ghost appears. Hamlet addresses the apparition as 'King, father; royal Dane' and implores it to reveal the reason for its nocturnal wanderings. The ghost simply beckons Hamlet to follow it to another place. Horatio and Marcellus beg Hamlet not to obey the ghost, fearing it would be dangerous and could even lead to his death; but Hamlet ignores his friends' warnings, breaks away from them when they try to physically restrain him, and follows the Ghost. Horatio and Marcellus are convinced that 'something is rotten in the state of Denmark' and decide to follow Hamlet.

0.text: Diomedes sends his servant with a message to Cressida about how he just beat down her ex-boyfriend. He also sends along Troilus's horse as proof that he's now Cressida's 'knight' in shining armor. Agamemnon appears and lists all the Greeks who have been killed, including Achilles' lover, Patroclus. He and Diomedes run off to get reinforcements while Nestor shows up to deliver the bad news about Patroclus. Then he tells us that Hector is running around the battlefield mowing down Greek warriors like a one-man army. Ulysses runs up and says that Achilles is 'weeping, cursing' and 'vowing vengeance' for Patroclus' death. We find out that Achilles and his gang of hooligan 'Myrmidons' are out for Hector's blood. Ajax runs in looking to kill Troilus.

Agamemnon and Diomedes depart to rally reinforcements, while Nestor arrives to deliver the sad news about Patroclus. Hector roams the battlefield, slaying Greek warriors one by one. Ulysses emerges, stating that Achilles 'weeps, rages,' and 'swears vengeance' for Patroclus' demise. 0.text: On Christmas morning Jim wakes up to see the men coming in from their morning chores. They all shout 'Merry Christmas' to each other. Grandfather says particularly long prayers that morning and reads aloud from the Bible. He thanks God for Christmas. Narrator-Jim remarks that Grandfather had a special talent for saying prayers. They have waffles and sausage for breakfast. Jake tells them that the Shimerdas were happy with their presents, even Ambrosch. That afternoon Jake and Jim play marbles while Otto writes a letter to his mother, as he does every Christmas. At 4pm Mr. Shimerda shows up with his rabbit-skin winter gear. He's there to thank them for everything they've done for his family. He seems to be very content, though it's only a break from his constant sadness. At 9pm, he leaves to go home. As he departs, he makes the sign of the cross over Grandmother and tells her that she's a good woman. He adds that the prayers of all good people are good.

0.text: Isabel is doing a lot of thinking. We learn about her thoughts on her marriage to Osmond and Lord Warburton's pursuit of Pansy. Isabel wonders if she gave a false image of herself to Osmond when they first got involved. Isabel feels certain that Osmond hates her, because she doesn't have a sense of 'tradition.' Well, of course not - isn't her originality the very thing that people love about her? Not only does he hate her opinions and beliefs, he also takes offense to the whole manner with which she conducts her life. We discover the grim truth behind their relationship: Osmond has gradually gained total control of Isabel, who was once so proud and independent. Isabel and Osmond have barely been speaking to one another. Isabel knows that Osmond is upset and jealous about Ralph's stay in Rome. Isabel has not told Ralph how miserable her life is. 0.text: Jim finally says good-bye and leaves for Black Hawk. Jim is sad to leave Ambrosch, whom he likes so much. He tells him and Rudolph that they'll go hunting together next summer. Jim doesn't enjoy his day in Black Hawk because he doesn't recognize most of the people there. He hangs out with Anton Jelinek and an old lawyer who fills him in on the details of the Cutter case. He walks outside of the town to look at the landscape. He feels at home again. He stumbles on the old road that leads out to his grandfather's old farm. It's mostly been ploughed under. Jim sits down and looks out at the sun. He remembers the night he arrived on the train from Virginia. He feels as though he and Antonia walked on the road of destiny to get where they are today, and that they possess the past together.

0.text: The witches again meet at an open place, this time with Hecate, the goddess of witches, who looks pretty angry. Hecate lays into the weird sisters in a lengthy, rhyming speech that sounds a bit like a nursery rhyme. She's super irritated that they were meddling in the affairs of Macbeth without consulting her first, as she could've done a better job. Also, she points out, Macbeth isn't devoted to them, only to himself. But, fine, Hecate will clean up this mess. She tells them to all meet in the morning, when Macbeth will come to know his destiny, whatever that means. Then there's a catchy witch song and dance, and everyone exits after Hecate. FYI: Some literary critics believe that these scene is way too hokey to be Shakespeare's work, so it must have been added to the play some time between the time the play was first written and its publication in the first folio , which was after Shakespeare's death . A fellow playwright, Thomas Middleton, may have written the snazzy songs in this scene.

2.text:
In English:

The witches assemble once more at an open place, this time with Hecate, the Goddess of witches, looking very furious. Hecate scolds the sisters in an extended, rhyming speech that recalls nursery rhymes. She's surprised they meddled in Macbeth's affairs without her approval, as she would have handled it better. Furthermore, she points out that Macbeth isn't dedicated to them but rather to himself. However, Hecate intends to put an end to this chaos. They command all to assemble in the morning upon Macbeth learning his fate, though I'm unsure of the significance. Following this, there's a delightful witch's song and dance, and each departs when Hecate does. (Note: Some literary critics consider this scene segment too kitschy to be from Shakespeare himself, implying it was penned by another playwright, Thomas Middleton, between the play's composition and its publication in the First Folio post-Shakespeare's death.)

Furthermore, she emphasizes that Macbeth pledged allegiance to himself rather than to them. Nevertheless, Hecate plans to quell the chaos. She commands everyone to reunite in the morning upon Macbeth's realization of his fate, though I am unsure of the implication. (Note: Some literary critics argue that this scene passage is too sentimental to have originated from Shakespeare himself, and that it might have been penned by Thomas Middleton between the composition and the play's publication in the First Folio posthumously.)

0.text: Elsewhere in the castle, Lady Macbeth expresses despair and sends a servant to fetch her husband. Macbeth enters and tells his wife that he too is discontented, saying that his mind is 'full of scorpions'. He feels that the business that they began by killing Duncan is not yet complete because there are still threats to the throne that must be eliminated. Macbeth tells his wife that he has planned 'a deed of dreadful note' for Banquo and Fleance and urges her to be jovial and kind to Banquo during the evening's feast, in order to lure their next victim into a false sense of security

0.text: Lydgate was indifferent to the voting on the question of chaplaincy at the hospital. Having met Farebrother and been drawn to him, he faces a dilemma. His personal preference is for Farebrother, who has a humane touch and who has been serving as chaplain all along without pay. Now that the post is an earned one, it seems unfair to deprive him. On the other hand, Bulstrode is Lydgates main backer in the town, where he anticipates serious oppositions to his plans for medical reform. Lydgate, therefore, attends the meeting in a confused state. There is heated discussion much of personal, among the members who have earlier assembled. Lydgate comes in last and finds them equally divided. Ultimately, his casting vote is decided by his smarting ego. Mr. Wrench, an old style medical practitioner, declares that it is well known that Lydgate will vote will Bulstrode. Incensed, Lydgate does just that. So Mr. Tyke becomes the hospital chaplain. Farebrother meanwhile, continues to meet Lydgate with the same friendliness as before. But his skepticism and tolerant attitude dont impress Lydgate favorably.

2.text:
Lydgate remained neutral towards the voice of the hospital chaplain. After meeting Farebrother and being drawn to him, he found himself in a dilemma. Personally, he favored Farebrother, who was kind and had served as chaplain for a long time without pay. However, now that the position was being paid, it seemed unfair to deny him. On the other hand, Bulstrode was Lydgate's most important supporter in the city, where he faced significant opposition to his medical reform plans. Therefore, Lydgate entered the assembly with an uncertain mood. There were heated discussions among the already gathered members. Eventually, Lydgate arrived and found them evenly divided. In the end, his decisive vote influenced his wounded ego. Mr. Wrench, an old school doctor, announced that it was common knowledge that Lydgate would vote for Bulstrode. This enraged Lydgate, and he indeed voted with Bulstrode. Consequently, Mr. Tyke became the new hospital chaplain. Meanwhile, Farebrother remained friendly with Lydgate. However, his skepticism and patient demeanor did not impress Lydgate positively.

0.text: Book II, Chapter 6 Carrie accompanies the Gormers to one of their new houses and while there meets George Dorset while taking a walk. He pleads with her to give him some proof of his wife's infidelities, implying that he wants to divorce her and marry Lily instead. Lily becomes afraid and runs away from him, telling him she cannot help. When she returns to the Gormer house, Mrs. Gormer informs her that Bertha Dorset had been there for a visit. Lily head back to the city and finds a place in a hotel, paying more for her rent than she can afford. She is soon visited by Mr. Dorset who implores her to help him out of his situation, but Lily refuses to reveal anything. She then goes to visit Carrie Fisher and finds Rosedale in Carrie's house, most likely invited there so he and Lily could meet. After the dinner Carrie talks with Lily alone, and tells her that in order to defeat Bertha Dorset, Lily will have to either marry Mr. Dorset or marry someone else.

0.text: The King and Laertes are discussing the crime that has been committed by Hamlet when a messenger arrives bearing a letter announcing Hamlet's impending return. Claudius requests that Laertes help to kill the Prince. Laertes, seeking to avenge his father is all too willing. He plans to poison his sword and use it to slay Hamlet. The king agrees to this plan and says that if it fails, he will give Hamlet a poisoned cup of wine. The Queen enters and announces that Ophelia has drowned. Laertes laments her death and leaves. Claudius tells Gertrude that he has been calming Laertes and that they should follow lest this news cause his temper to flare again.

2.text: The king and Laertes discuss what Hamlet has done. A messenger enters, bearing a message announcing Hamlet's arrival. Claudius asks Laertes to help him in Hamlet's murder. Laertes, seeking revenge for his father, agrees. He plans to poison his sword and kill Hamlet with it. The king approves of this plan and says, if it fails, he will give Hamlet a poisoned glass of wine. Gertrude enters and announces Ophelia's death by drowning. Laertes mourns her death and leaves. Claudius tells Gertrude he has calmed Laertes down and they should go to protect him from further agitation.

We speak of Irmen and Laertes in relation to Hamlet's actions. Suddenly, a messenger enters and announces: 'Hamlet has arrived!' Claudius asks Laertes to fetch him, so we can avenge our father's death with Hamlet. Laertes agrees. He plans to poison his sword and kill Hamlet with it. The king agrees to the plan and says: 'If it fails, Hamlet will receive a poisoned glass of wine.' Gertrude enters and announces: 'Ophelia has drowned.' She mourns her and leaves. Translation:

Wir sprechen von Irmen und Laertes in Beziehung auf Hamlets Tätigkeiten. Plötzlich tritt ein Boten herein und verkündet: 'Hamlet ist angekommen!' Claudius bittet Laertes, ihn holen, damit wir mit Hamlet unserem Vaters Tod rächen können. Laertes stimmt zu. Er plant, sein Schwert mit Gift zu vergiften und Hamlet mit ihm zu töten. Der König stimmt dem Plan zu und sagt: 'Wenn es fehlschlägt, erhält Hamlet ein vergiftetes Glas Wein.' Gertrud tritt herein und verkündet: 'Ophelia ist ertrunken.' Sie weint sie an und geht. Claudius sagt Gertrud: 'Ich habe Laertes getrostet und bat dich, ihn vor zusätzlichen Sorgen zu schützen.'

(Note: In this translation, I assumed the source language to be Modern Standard German. If you meant a specific German dialect or variation, please let me know.)
