0.text: The old neighbor has problems of her own. She's a beggar and a thief, but for now, she's Jimmie's only option. She dispatches Jimmie to buy her a can of beer. Unfortunately, Jimmie's father intercepts him and steals the beer. He can't cope with the 'livin hell' at home either. Jimmie hangs out before returning to the apartment. He can hear his parents fighting, threatening, and perpetrating violence on each other; the neighbors comment on how 'Ol' Johnson' is at it again. Apparently the parents have earned a bit of a reputation for hand-to-hand combat. Jimmie finally gathers the courage to return, and when he does, he finds his drunken parents passed out on the floor. He and Maggie hold each other, quivering and scared, until 'the ghost mists of dawn' arrive.

2.text: The old neighbor has her own issues. She is a beggar and a thief, but for now, she is Jimmy's only option. She sends Jimmy to buy her a can of beer. But Jimmy's father jealously and quickly snatches the beer bottle away. He can endure the 'hellish life' at home for longer. Jimmy hesitates to return to the apartment. He hears his parents arguing, threatening and threatening to engage in violent confrontations; the neighbors comment that 'Old Johnson' has caused trouble again. Apparently, his parents have received a summons for violent disputes. Jimmy gathers courage and goes back, finding her lying on the floor. He and Maggie cling to each other, trembling and terrifyingly, until the 'spectral mists of dawn' appear.

4.text:
Bierflasche. Er kann länger in der 'höllischen Existenz' zu Hause verweilen. Jimmy hinkt zurück, er hört seine Eltern streiten, drohen und drohen, in gewalttätige Auseinandersetzungen einzugehen; die Nachbarn kommentieren, dass 'Alte Johnson' erneut Probleme verursacht hat. Offenbar haben seine Eltern eine Anzeige wegen gewalttätiger Auseinandersetzungen erhalten. Jimmy findet Mut und geht wieder zurück, findet sie auf dem Boden liegend. Er und Maggie klingen aneinander, zitternd und entsetzlich, bis die 'spektralen Nebel der Morgendämmerung' erscheinen.

Translation:
The old neighbor has her own problems. She is a beggar and a burglar, but for now, she is Jimmy's only option. She sends Jimmy to buy her a can of beer. But Jimmy's father is jealous and quickly takes the beer bottle away. He can endure the 'hellish life' at home for longer. Jimmy hesitates to return to the apartment. He hears his parents arguing, threatening and threatening to engage in violent disputes; the neighbors comment that 'Old Johnson' has caused trouble again. Apparently, his parents have filed a report for violent disputes. Jimmy gathers courage and goes back, finding her lying on the floor. He and Maggie cling to each other, trembling and terrifyingly, until the 'spectral mists of dawn' appear.

0.text: The Duchess is fetched by the Queens soldier. She appears happy to see Alice and is relieved that she will not be executed. The conversation between the Duchess and Alice is packed with statements and the moral of each of these statements. This is enough to disorient Alice, since she has never thought that everything that she said would eventually have a moral. Frightened by the Queen, the Duchess finally leaves and Alice is now encouraged by the Queen to meet the Mock Turtle. The Queen orders the Gryphon  to take Alice to the Mock turtle. The Mock Turtle, sitting on a little rocky ledge, is sad and constantly sighing. Alice requests the Mock Turtle to tell her, his history. The Mock Turtle very proudly lists the various subjects that were taught to him. The subjects include, Reeling and Writhing and the different branches of Arithmetic . Apart from this were Mystery, Seaography, Drawling, Stretching and Fainting. What excites Alice about the Mock Turtles school is that the duration of attendance would lessen day by day. The Mock turtle asserts that it is 'because of this that they are called lessons'.

2.text:
could have. The Duchess is surprised by the Queen and eventually leaves. Alice is then encouraged by the Queen to meet the Mock Turtle. The Queen orders the Gryphon to bring Alice to the Mock Turtle. The Mock Turtle sits on a small rocky ledge and is sad and continually sighing. Alice asks the Mock Turtle to tell her his story. The Mock Turtle is proud and lists the various teachers who have instructed him. Among these were Rollen und Falten (Rolling and Folding) and die verschiedenen Zweige der Arithmetik (the different branches of Arithmetic). Darüber hinaus gab es Geheimnisse, Seemanschaft, Zeichnen, Dehnen und Verblassen (Secrets, Seamanship, Drawing, Stretching and Fading). Was Alice an den Mock-Turtle-Schulen interessiert, ist, dass die Dauer ihrer Anwesenheit jeden Tag verkürzt wird. Der Mock Turtle sagt, 'deswegen heißen sie Unterricht' (that's why they call it instruction).

Translation note: In order to maintain the original meaning and context, I have translated 'Lehrstunden' (lessons) as 'Underricht' (instruction) since the English text uses 'instruction' to describe the Mock Turtle's school. I have also translated 'Anwesenheit' (presence) as 'Anwesenheit' in the target language to preserve the original meaning.

0.text: More Links It is harvest time, and Mrs. Poyser is the heroine of the valley for speaking her mind to the old squire. Mr. Irwine and his mother admire Mrs. Poyser for her backbone but doubt the old squire will be around much longer. Both Mrs. Poyser and Adam notice changes in Hetty after she receives the letter. She is quieter, more cooperative and less vain. She does her work without scolding and does not want to go anywhere. Adam takes it as a sign she is getting over Arthur. He feels hopeful. The narrator comments on Adam's love for Hetty. On the one hand, he falls in love with her because of the way she looks; he has no idea who she is. But, the narrator thinks Adam's love comes from his strength not his weakness, for love is like a mysterious music set off by beauty, and Hetty touches all the deep places in Adam. His work is prospering, and he can think of marriage. Jonathan Burge offers him a partnership, and so with his two jobs, he can afford to buy a house.

2.text:
It's harvest time, and Mrs. Poyser is the heroine of the valley, as she spoke to the old squire. Mr. Irwine and his mother value Mrs. Poyser for her backbone, but they doubt if the old squire will stay on this earth for long. Both Mrs. Poyser and Adam notice changes in Hetty after the arrival of the letter. She is calmer, more cooperative, and less vain. She does her work without complaints and does not want to go out anymore. Adam sees this as a sign that she has recovered from Arthur. He is optimistic. The narrator comments on Adam's love for Hetty. Certainly, he loves her for her looks, but he doesn't know who she is. But the narrator thinks, Adam's love comes from his strength, not his weakness, because love is like a mysterious piece of music that awakens the deepest feelings, and Hetty touches all of Adam's sensitivities. His work is successful, and he can think about marriage. Jonathan Burge offers him a partnership, and with his two jobs, he can buy a house.

(Translation of Chapter 32 from 'Adam Bede' by George Eliot from German to English)

Es ist Erntezeit, und Mrs. Poyser ist die Heldin des Tals, denn sie redete dem alten Squire an. Herr Irwine und seine Mutter schätzen Mrs. Poyser wegen ihres Rückgrats, aber sie haben Zweifel, ob der alte Squire lange auf dieser Erde bleiben wird. Beide Mrs. Poyser und Adam bemerken Veränderungen bei Hetty nach Ankunft des Briefes. Sie ist ruhiger, kooperativer und weniger eitel. His work is successful, and he can consider marriage. Jonathan Burge offers him a partnership, and with his two jobs, he can buy a house.

Babbitt works meticulously and obediently on 'Style and Order and Other Enigmas' and overcomes these obstacles. He submits clear and concise statements, expressing his views on housing economics.

However, his participation in the convention is criticized, as his tone resembles that of the well-known real estate speculator Cecil Rountree.

Undeterred, Babbitt does not react immediately but spends his evenings with the delegates of the event at a brothel and cultivates relationships with them.

He keeps the details of his evening activities a secret and returns to Zenith, where things remain as usual.

0.text: The Lilliputian emperor is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he rewards him with some court diversions. The diversions, however, prove to be quite different than one might expect. It is the Lilliputian court custom that men seeking political office demonstrate their agility in rope dancing, among other things. How long and how skillfully a candidate can dance upon a rope determines his tenure in office. Of the candidates, two are particularly adept: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other diversions include noblemen competing for official favor by crawling under or leaping over a stick, a feat for which they are then rewarded with various colored threads. Gulliver also reviews the Emperor's troops; he stands, legs apart, while the tiny men march through. As a result of Gulliver's cooperation, a pact between Gulliver and the Emperor is agreed on. Gulliver is granted limited freedom on certain conditions. In return for abiding by the conditions, he will receive food sufficient for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles in proper form, and the Emperor frees him.

2.text:
In English: Nobles compete for the favor of the Emperor by crawling under or jumping over a stick and are rewarded with differently colored threads. Gulliver observes the Emperor's troops marching past, standing stiffly at attention, while the little men pass by. Due to Gulliver's cooperation, a contract is drawn up between Gulliver and the Emperor. Under certain conditions, you will be given limited freedom. In return for adhering to these conditions, he receives food for 1728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the contract articles truthfully and allows the Emperor to release him.

In German: Edelleute konkurrieren um die Gunst des Kaisers, indem sie unter oder über einem Stock kriechen oder springen, für das sie unterschiedlich farbige Fäden belohnt werden. Gulliver beobachtet, wie die Truppen des Kaisers vorbeimarschieren, steif aufgestellt, während die winzigen Männer vorbeimarschieren. Aufgrund von Gullivers Zusammenarbeit wird zwischen Gulliver und dem Kaiser ein Vertrag geschlossen. Unter bestimmten Bedingungen erhalten Sie Gulliver begrenzte Freiheit. Im Austausch für die Einhaltung dieser Bedingungen erhält er Nahrung für 1728 Lilliputier. Gulliver schwört die Vertragsartikel richtig und erlaubt dem Kaiser, ihn freizulassen.

This is a faithful translation of the original English text into German, preserving all the original meaning and context.

0.text: The Mail On a Friday night in late November of 1775, a mail coach wends its way from London to Dover. The journey proves so treacherous that the three passengers must dismount from the carriage and hike alongside it as it climbs a steep hill. From out of the great mists, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak to Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react warily, fearing that they have come upon a highwayman or robber. Mr. Lorry, however, recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, the odd-job man at Tellson's, and accepts his message. The note that Jerry passes him reads: 'Wait at Dover for Mam'selle. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's with this reply: 'Recalled to Life. Confused and troubled by the 'blazing strange message,' Jerry rides on to deliver it

2.text: Friday evening in November of the year 1775, a postchaise leaves London for Dover. The journey proves dangerous, and the three passengers are asked to help push the carriage up a steep incline. Out of the dense fog emerges a rider on horseback, who wishes to speak with Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react suspiciously, fearing a highwayman or thief. But Mr. Lorry recognizes the voice of the rider as that of Jerry Cruncher, the errand-boy at Tellson's, and hands him the paper. The piece of paper that Jerry receives contains the words: 'Wait for Miss Pross. Lorry orders Jerry, 'Recalled to Life,' to reply. Jerry is uneasy and surprised by the 'strangely fiery message' and rides on to deliver it.'

4.text: Thursday evening in November of the year 1775, a postchaise departed from London towards Dover. The journey was dangerous, and the three passengers were ordered to push the wagon up a steep ramp. Suddenly, out of the dense fog appeared a rider on horseback, who called out to Jarvis Lorry from Tellson's Bank. The travelers reacted suspiciously, fearing a highwayman or thief. But Mr. Lorry recognized the voice of the rider as that of Jerry Cruncher, Tellson's messenger, and handed him the paper. The paper that Jerry received contained the words: 'Wait for Miss Pross.' Lorry instructed Jerry to tell her 'Wake me up,' and Jerry was both excited and surprised by the 'strangely urgent message' and rode off to deliver it.

6.text:
Thursday evening in November of the year 1775, a mail coach departed from London towards Dover. The journey was dangerous, and the three passengers were ordered to push the wagon up a steep ramp. Suddenly, out of the thick fog bank appeared a rider on horseback and called out to Jarvis Lorry from Tellson's Bank. The travelers reacted suspiciously, fearing a highwayman or thief. But Mr. Lorry recognized the voice of the rider as that of Jerry Cruncher, Tellson's Bank's messenger, and handed him the paper. The paper Jerry received contained the words: 'Wait for Miss Pross.' Lorry instructed Jerry to say, 'Wake me up,' and Jerry was excited and surprised by the 'strange urgent message' and rode away to carry it out.

(Note: In this translation, I have attempted to preserve the original meaning and context while translating the passage from German to English. The tone and style have been kept as close to the original as possible.)

8.text:
Donnerstagabend im November des Jahres 1775 verließen eine Postkutsche von London nach Dover. Die Reise war gefährlich, und die drei Passagieren wurden aufgefordert, den Wagen an einem steilen Rampen anzupfen. Plötzlich erschien aus dem dicken Nebelbank ein Reiter auf Pferd und rief: 'Jarvis Lorry von Tellson's Bank!' Die Reisenden reagierten misstrauisch, fürchten doch ein Raubritter oder Dieb. Aber Mr. Lorry erkannte die Stimme des Reiters als die des Jerry Cruncher, des Boten von Tellson's Bank, und gab ihm das Papier. Das Papier, das Jerry erhielt, enthielt die Worte: 'Warte auf Miss Pross.' Lorry befehlig Jerry, 'Erweck mich auf,' zu sagen, und Jerry war erregt und überrascht von der 'seltsamen dringenden Nachricht' und reitete fort, sie auszuführen.

Translation:
Thursday evening in November of the year 1775, a postchaise departed from London to Dover. The journey was dangerous, and the three passengers were ordered to help push the wagon up a steep ramp. Suddenly, out of the thick fog appeared a rider on horseback and called out: 'Jarvis Lorry from Tellson's Bank!' The travelers reacted suspiciously, fearing a highwayman or thief. But Mr. Lorry recognized the voice of the rider as that of Jerry Cruncher, the messenger from Tellson's Bank, and handed him the paper. The paper that Jerry received contained the words: 'Wait for Miss Pross.' Lorry instructed Jerry to say, 'Wake me up,' and Jerry was excited and surprised by the 'strange urgent message' and rode off to carry it out.

In this translation, we have preserved the original meaning and context while translating the passage from English to German.

0.text: The Governess and Miles, alone at last, speak cagily about Miles's explorations of the grounds over the past day or so, when he's been left to his own devices. Finally, it's time to get everything out in the open. The Governess insists that she's only there to help Miles and to be with him - and he sees that she wants him to tell her everything. As he prepares to confess, she sees for the first time that he's afraid - of her. Miles nervously tells the Governess that he'll tell her anything, but not just now; he says he has to go see Luke . Before she lets him go, the Governess just asks him one thing: did he take the letter she left in the hall yesterday?

2.text: The governess and Miles are now alone and speak cautiously about Miles' investigations in the gardens of the past few days, during which he was alone. It's about time to uncover everything. As he prepares to confess it all, he sees for the first time that she is afraid - of him. Miles tells the governess that he will tell her everything, but not yet; he needs to meet with Luke first. Before he leaves, she asks him only one more thing: does he have the notebook she left behind in the corridor yesterday?

0.text: Spring arrives, and Gray Beaver finishes the journey. White Fang is one year old, and next to Lip-lip, he is the largest yearling. He continues to have his battles with other dogs. When he fights with Baseek over a piece of shinbone, White Fang rips Baseeks right ear and wounds him on the shoulder. Baseek, old and weak, gives up. In mid-summer, White Fang encounters Kiche, who has now forgotten him and has had a new litter. She hovers protectively around her litter, trying to drive White Fang away. When White Fang is three years old, there is a great famine in the land. Only the strong will survive, for the Indians eat the weaker dogs. The Indians also eat the soft-tanned leather of their moccasins and mittens to fill their stomachs. White Fang escapes into the forest to hunt on his own, at times robbing rabbit snares and at times capturing small game, like squirrels and woodmice. At the end of the famine, White Fang meets Lip-lip, with whom he fights until Lip-lip is killed. He then returns to the village and is received warmly and given plenty of fish.

2.text: Spring comes, and Gray Beaver ends his journey. White Paws is one year old and next to Lip-lip the biggest young dog. He continues his fights with other dogs. In a fight over a piece of bone with Baseek, White Paws tears off Baseek's right ear and injures him on the shoulder blade. Baseek, old and weak, lies down. In the summer afternoon, White Paws meets Kiche, who has forgotten about him and has given birth to a new litter. She protects her litter anxiously and tries to chase White Paws away. When White Paws is three years old, a great famine hits the land. Only the strong survive, as the Indians eat the weaker dogs. The Indians also eat the soft leather of their moccasins and gloves to keep their stomachs full. White Paws flees into the forest to hunt alone, sometimes stealing Rabbit-traps and sometimes catching small animals like squirrels and mice. At the end of the famine, White Paws meets Lip-lip again, with whom he had fought, until Lip-lip is killed. Then he returns to the village and is warmly welcomed back and rewarded with many fish.

0.text: It is a cold, wet November afternoon when the novel opens at Gateshead, the home of Jane Eyre's relatives, the Reeds. Jane and the Reed children, Eliza, John, and Georgiana sit in the drawing room. Jane's aunt is angry with her, purposely excluding her from the rest of the family, so Jane sits alone in a window seat, reading Bewick's History of British Birds. As she quietly reads, her cousin John torments her, reminding her of her precarious position within the household. As orphaned niece of Mrs. Reed, she should not be allowed to live with gentlemen's children. John throws a book at Jane and she calls him a 'murderer' and 'slave-driver.' The two children fight, and Jane is blamed for the quarrel. As punishment, she is banished to the red-room.

One says that Hetty had borne the baby in her house and had then run off with it the following day. The other reports finding the dead baby lying half-buried in a small grove and adds that when he had returned to the spot with a constable, they found Hetty sitting there in a state of shock. The case is clear and the verdict of guilty is quickly pronounced. When the judge assigns the death sentence, Hetty shrieks and faints, and is carried from the courtroom.

0.text: When Emma calls for Harriet at the Abbey Farm, the excited girl tells Emma that she has visited with Martin's mother and two sisters. On the way home, Emma decides to stop at the Westons and is disappointed to find they are not home. As she turns to leave, the Westons arrive in their carriage. They inform Emma that Frank Churchill will be arriving the next day and staying for a fortnight. They assure Emma that they will bring Frank to Hartfield. The next day Mr. Weston and Frank call at Woodhouse. Emma finds Frank to be a very good-looking gentleman of well-bred manners; she is also impressed by his lively spirit. He praises Mrs. Weston for her pretty looks and elegant manners. Emma immediately likes Frank and imaginatively concludes that Frank also has an interest in her. She barely notices that he plans to call on Jane Fairfax next since he already knows her.

2.text: At Emma's call to Harriet at Abbey Farm, the excited girl Emma relates that she had been with Mrs. Martin and her two sisters. On her way home, Emma intends to visit the Westons, but is disappointed when they are not there. As she is about to depart, the Westons arrive in their carriage. They inform Emma that Frank Churchill will arrive the following day and stay for two weeks. They assure her they will bring Frank to Hartfield. The following day, Mr. Weston and Frank arrive at Woodhouse. Emma finds Frank to be a very distinguished gentleman with refined manners; she is also captivated by his spirited disposition. He compliments the beauty and elegant manners of Mrs. Weston. Emma instantly warms to Frank and supposes he might also be interested in her. She barely perceives that he intends to see Jane Fairfax the next day, as they are already acquainted.

They informed Emma that Frank Churchill would arrive the following day and stay for two weeks. They promised to bring him to Hartfield. The following day, Mr. Weston and Frank Churchill arrived. Emma met Frank, a very demanding gentleman with refined manners, and found him very attractive. She was also captivated by his lively demeanor. He praised the beauty and polite manners of Mrs. Weston. Suddenly, Emma develops sympathy for Frank and suspects that he may also be interested in her. Almost imperceptibly to her, he plans to meet with Jane Fairfax the following day, as they are already acquainted.

Almost unnoticed by her, he planned to meet with Jane Fairfax the next day, as they already knew each other.

0.text: Five Years Later It is now 1780. Tellson's Bank in London prides itself on being 'very small, very dark, very ugly, very incommodious. Were it more welcoming, the bank's partners believe, it would lose its status as a respectable business. It is located by Temple Bar, the spot where, until recently, the government displayed the heads of executed criminals. The narrator explains that at this time, 'death was a recipe much in vogue,' used against all manner of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, employed by Tellson's as a runner and messenger, wakes up in his small apartment, located in an unsavory London neighborhood. He begins the day by yelling at his wife for 'praying against' him; he throws his muddy boot at her. Around nine o'clock, Cruncher and his young son camp outside Tellson's Bank, where they await the bankers' instructions. When an indoor messenger calls for a porter, Cruncher takes off to do the job. As young Jerry sits alone, he wonders why his father's fingers always have rust on them

2.text: Five years later, in 1780: Tellson's Bank in London is proud to be 'very small, very dark, very unattractive and very uncomfortable.' The shareholders believe it would be more pleasant if it had lost its reputable business standing. It is located near Temple Bar, the place where the government once displayed the heads of executed criminals. At this time, the narrator reports that 'death was a very popular recipe' for dealing with all kinds of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves and counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, who works for Tellson's Bank as a runner and messenger, is awakened from his wretched London bed. He begins his workday by cursing his wife for 'praying against me'; he throws his dirty boots in her face. At nine o'clock, Cruncher and his young son stand before Tellson's Bank and wait for instructions from the bankers. When an internal messenger call comes, Cruncher sets off to complete the task. While young Jerry is left alone, his sons wonder why their father's fingers are always rusty.

50.text:
At London's Tellson's Bank, Cruncher waits on orders from the bankers. When he is sent on a mission, Cruncher assumes the role of the bank's internal emissary. The children ask Cruncher why his fingers are always red.

Five years later, 1780: London's Tellson's Bank is proud of its 'very small, very dark, very hidden and very unpleasant' appearance. Shareholders complain that the building could be better utilized and adapted to its superior business location. The bank building is located near Temple Bar, where the skins of executed criminals were displayed before government buildings. In those days, the death penalty was fashionable for all types of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves and counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, who serves as a messenger and errand boy for Tellson's Bank, is dissatisfied with his London surroundings due to his wife's singing; he throws her shoes away. At eight o'clock, Cruncher and his child stand before Tellson's Bank to receive instructions from the bankers. When he is sent on a solo mission, Cruncher assumes the role of the bank's internal emissary. The children ask Cruncher why his fingers are always red.

0.text: The Duke finds Mariana, and exchanges a few cursory words with her. Isabella enters as Mariana leaves, to tell the Duke that she has agreed to Angelo's plan, and describes the place of meeting. Isabella said that she told Angelo she could only stay briefly, and that she would be bringing a servant with her, which means she can bring Mariana without suspicion. Isabella has a word with Mariana, and Mariana agrees to go with the plan, provided the 'friar' agrees, which he does. The Duke still has to assure her that she is doing no sin, because she is only fulfilling the contract she had with Angelo some time ago.

0.text: Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering on his mission while he waits for the young woman who is Lucie Manette. She arrives believing that there is some property belonging to her late father in Paris, but Mr. Lorry breaks the news to her that her father is still alive. He is Dr. Manette who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the last eighteen years. The French authorities have recently released him and as he was one of Tellson's Bank's clients, Mr. Lorry has been sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will take the responsibility for caring for her father and bringing him back to health. Lucie is taken aback at this news and she faints. A large red-haired woman runs into the room pushing Mr. Lorry aside and going to the young lady's assistance using smelling salts and cold water to revive her.

2.text:
Mr. Lorry reaches the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, he spends the day pondering his task, until young Lucie Manette arrives. She comes believing that her father owns something in Paris, but Mr. Lorry brings her the news that her father is still alive. It is Dr. Manette, who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the last 18 years. The French authorities have released him, and as a customer of Tellson's Bank, Mr. Lorry had fetched him there to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will feel responsible for her father's care and restoration. Lucie is shocked by this news and takes her leave. A large red-haired woman named Darnay bursts in, driving Mr. Lorry away and taking the young woman under her wing, reviving her with soap bubbles and cold water.

Translation:

Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and rests before dedicating his day to contemplating his duty. Young Lucie Manette then arrives, expecting her father to possess something in Paris. However, Mr. Lorry delivers the message that her father is alive. This is Dr. Manette, who has spent the last 18 years in the Bastille in Paris. The French authorities have freed him, and as a client of Tellson's Bank, Mr. Lorry had brought him there for identification. It is anticipated that Lucie will assume responsibility for her father's care and recovery. Lucie is taken aback by this revelation and departs. A robust red-haired woman named Darnay rushes in, chasing Mr. Lorry away and assuming care for the young woman, rejuvenating her with soap bubbles and cold water.

0.text: Emma is thoroughly pleased with her evening at the Coles, but she is uncertain about the appropriateness of telling Frank about her suspicions about Jane or acknowledging the superiority of Jane's musical abilities. At the Coles' party, Harriet heard that Mr. Martin had dined with the Cox family, and there is a rumor that a Cox daughter would like to marry Mr. Martin. To distract and protect Harriet, Emma accompanies her on a shopping trip. They then decide to pay a visit to the Bates household and run into Frank and Mrs. Weston on their way. The visit seems to have been Frank's idea, but he offers to stay with Emma and send Mrs. Weston to make the visit on her own. Emma sends him along, knowing that he will later come see her at Hartfield, but Miss Bates then comes into the shop to ask Emma to come give her opinion of Jane's new pianoforte. In her rambling, Miss Bates reveals that Mr. Knightley has sent his last apples of the season to Jane, who is particularly fond of them.

2.text:
New piano. During her confusion, Miss Bates reveals that Mr. Knightley sent the last apples of the season to Jane, who is very pleased about it.

Emma enjoys her evening at the Coles, but is uncertain whether to confide in Frank about her suspicion regarding Jane or her musical superiority. At the Coles' party, Harriet learns that Mr. Martin sat at the table with the Coxes, and there are rumors of a Cox daughter who intends to marry Mr. Martin. To distract and protect Harriet, Emma accompanies her on a shopping trip. Afterwards, they decide to pay a visit to the Bates family, and encounter Frank and Mrs. Weston there. The visit seems to have been Frank's idea, but he offers to let Emma stay and send Mrs. Weston alone, to make the visit. Emma sends him away, knowing he will come to Hartfield later, but then Miss Bates appears in the shop to ask Emma's opinion about Jane's new piano. In the confusion, Miss Bates inadvertently reveals that Mr. Knightley sent the last apples of the season to Jane, who is very happy about the gift.

0.text: The Prison Door This first chapter contains little in the way of action, instead setting the scene and introducing the first of many symbols that will come to dominate the story. A crowd of somber, dreary-looking people has gathered outside the door of a prison in seventeenth-century Boston. The building's heavy oak door is studded with iron spikes, and the prison appears to have been constructed to hold dangerous criminals. No matter how optimistic the founders of new colonies may be, the narrator tells us, they invariably provide for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. This is true of the citizens of Boston, who built their prison some twenty years earlier. The one incongruity in the otherwise drab scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. The narrator suggests that it offers a reminder of Nature's kindness to the condemned; for his tale, he says, it will provide either a 'sweet moral blossom' or else some relief in the face of unrelenting sorrow and gloom

2.text:
Title: The Prison Gate
This first chapter offers little narrative progress, but serves the depiction of the scene and the introduction of the first of many symbols that will shape the story. A crowd of sad, threatening-looking people has gathered before the door of a prison in 17th century Boston. The building boasts a massive oak door with iron nails, and the prison seems to have provided shelter for dangerous criminals. Despite the enlightened intentions of the founders of the New Colonies, as the narrator informs us, the Boston residents had built the prison and the cemetery side by side. This was also the case for the residents of Boston who had built their prison approximately twenty years earlier. The only incongruity in the otherwise sad scene is the rosebush that grows beside the prison door. The narrator suspects that this rosebush offers either its rich bloom or something else in the face of unrelenting sadness and cruelty.

Translation:
Obwohl die Gründer der Neuen Kolonien, wie uns der Erzähler mitteilt, aufklärerische Absichten hatten, hatten Bostonianer das Gefängnis und den Friedhof nebeneinander gebaut. Das war auch der Fall für die Bostonianer, die ihr Gefängnis etwa zwanzig Jahre zuvor errichtet hatten. Das einzige Widerspruch in der sonst trüben Szene ist der Rosenhain, der neben der Gefängnistür wächst. Der Erzähler vermutet, dass dieser Rosenhain mit seinem reichen Duft oder etwas Anderes im Gegensatz zu den endlosen Gehorsamskonventionen und Grausamkeiten steht.

In this text, the narrator informs us that although the founders of the New Colonies had good intentions, Bostonians had built a prison and a cemetery next to each other, and this was true for the prison built twenty years prior as well. The only thing that contrasts the otherwise dismal scene is a rose garden growing next to the prison door. The narrator speculates that the rose garden, with its rich fragrance or something else, is in opposition to the endless obedience conventions and cruelties.

0.text: Tom Foster moved to Winesburg with his grandmother as a teenager. She cleans Banker White's house. Tom used to be the stable boy at the Whites' house, but because he is rather dreamy and irresponsible, he lost that position. Now, he does odd jobs and is quite happy. His grandmother comes regularly to clean his rented rooms, and he has a rather oddly disciplined approach to life experiences. He wants to do things, but he chooses specific experiences and then goes out and intentionally lives them. For example, having fallen in love with Helen White, he limits what he allows himself to think about her. One night, he decides he ought to try drinking to see what it feels like. He buys a bottle of whiskey and walks about a mile north of town, where he sits on a bank of grass and gets drunk. In his drunkenness, he goes and talks to George Willard about Helen. George is upset at first, but then they cement a bond between them. Tom decides that, now that he has been drunk, he will not need to try it again.

Sir William Lucy, einer der Botschafter, informiert uns, dass Henry V.'s Ruf in England beschädigt wird, weil Somerset und York sich Siege gestohlen haben. Schließlich verkündet Somerset, dass er Kavallerie schicken wird, aber Sir William Lucy äußert Besorgnis, da die Reise sechs Stunden dauert. Sir William Lucy, one of the ambassadors, informs us that Henry V. in England is being tarnished by the conflicts between Somerset and York. Finally, Somerset declares he will send cavalry, but Sir William Lucy expresses concern since the journey takes six hours. Lucy tells Somerset: 'His fame lives in the world, his shame in you' - meaning Talbot's valor is admired worldwide, but Talbot would be disappointed in you because of your behavior.

0.text: It is summer at Longbourn; Lydia has gone to Brighton, and Mrs. Bennet and Kitty constantly complain of boredom. Mr. Bennett, as always, stays aloof and uninvolved. Elizabeth, remembering the contents of Darcys letter, is more bothered by her parents behavior than ever. She realizes they are totally mismatched and decides she will not marry until she finds someone with whom she can have a proper and supportive relationship. Unlike the bored Kitty and her mother, Elizabeth is eagerly awaiting her trip with the Gardiners. As she dreams about the northern tour, she receives a letter explaining that the trip has to be shortened to only Derbyshire. She is momentarily disappointed, for she has been looking forward to seeing the lake. The Gardiners take Elizabeth to Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner once resided. Pemberley, Darcys residence, is situated about five miles away. Elizabeth is persuaded by her aunt and uncle to visit Pemberley, since the family is away.

2.text: In Longbourn during the summer: Lydia has gone to Brighton, and Mrs. Bennett and Kitty lament the boredom constantly. Mr. Bennett remains as usual detached and uninvolved. Elizabeth recalls the contents of Darcy's letter and is more concerned than ever about her behavior towards her parents. They realize they are unsuited and decide not to marry until they encounter someone with a compatible and supportive relationship. The Gardiners take Elizabeth to Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner had lived before. Pemberley, the seat of the Darcys, is about five miles away. Elizabeth is encouraged by her aunt and uncle to visit Pemberley, as the family is away.

0.text: The scene is set in the evening at a post outside of Arras. It opens with a dialogue between Captain Carbon de Castel-Jaloux and Le Bret in which they indicate that the besieged French troops are miserable, depressed, and hungry. Since the Spanish troops have cut off their supplies, the French have no food. Cyrano seems to be the only one in camp that is not miserable. He is still awake even though most of the cadets are sleeping, for he has just traveled through the Spanish line in order to dispatch a letter to Roxane, as he does everyday. The letters that he writes give him great pleasure.

2.text: In the picture, it's evening in the camp at Arras. Captain Carbon de Castel-Jaloux and Le Bret are conversing, sharing the misery, despair, and hunger of the besieged French. Their supplies are cut off by the Spanish troops, and the French have no food. Cyrano seems to be the only one in the camp in good spirits. He stays awake, while the cadets mostly sleep, having just crossed the Spanish lines to deliver a message to Roxane, a daily ritual for him. The letters he writes bring him great joy.

The image shows the camp of Arras in the darkness. Captain Carbon de Castel-Jaloux and Le Bret are conversing, lamenting the misery, despair, and hunger of the besieged French. Their supplies are being obstructed by Spanish troops who deny them food. Cyrano seems to be the only one in high spirits in the camp. Translation:

The picture depicts the camp of Arras in the darkness. Captain Carbon de Castel-Jaloux and Le Bret are conversing, bemoaning the misery, despair, and hunger of the besieged French. Their supplies are being obstructed by Spanish troops who deny them food. Cyrano appears to be the only one in high spirits in the camp. He stays awake, while the cadets mostly sleep, as they had crossed the Spanish lines to serve as messengers for Roxane, as his letters attest, a daily ritual that brings him great pleasure.

13.text:
The image shows the camp of Arras in the darkness. Captain Carbon de Castel-Jaloux and Le Bret converse, lamenting the misery, despair, and hunger of the prisoners. Their supplies are hindered by Spanish troops, who deny them food. Cyrano seems to be the only one in high spirits in the camp. He stays awake, while most cadets sleep, as they have crossed the Spanish lines to serve as messengers for Roxane, as his letters prove, a daily ritual that brings him great pleasure.

(Translation:
Das Bild zeigt das Lager von Arras in der Dunkelheit. Kapitän Carbon de Castel-Jaloux und Le Bret unterhalten sich betrübt über die Elend, Verzweiflung und Hunger der Gefangenen. Ihre Versorgung werden sie von spanischen Truppen behindert, die ihnen Nahrung verweigern. Cyrano scheint der Einzige zu sein, der in hoher Stimmung im Lager ist. Er bleibt wach, während die meisten Kadetten schlafen, denn sie haben die spanischen Linien überschritten, um für Roxane als Boten zu dienen, wie seine Briefe beweisen, ein tägliches Ritual, das ihm großen Vergnügen bringt.

(Explanation:
The passage describes a scene in a prisoner camp at Arras during the night. Two men, Kapitän Carbon de Castel-Jaloux and Le Bret, are conversing sadly about the misery, despair, and hunger of the prisoners. Their supplies are being obstructed by Spanish troops, who refuse to give them food. Cyrano appears to be the only one in good spirits in the camp. He stays awake, while most cadets sleep, as they have crossed the Spanish lines to serve as messengers for Roxane, as his letters prove, a daily ritual that brings him great pleasure.)

0.text: In this short scene, Quince and Flute are searching for their missing friend, Bottom. They worry that 'Pyramus and Thisbe' won't be performed without him. Theseus is known for his generosity, and the actors believe they will potentially be rewarded with a lifelong pension for their stellar performance of this play. As they lament this lost opportunity, Bottom suddenly returns. His friends want to hear his story, but Bottom tells them there isn't time for that now: They must prepare for the play. He warns them to avoid onions and garlic so their breath will be sweet for the 'sweet comedy' they will perform.

2.text: In this short scene, Quincus and Flautus search for their missing friend, Bottom. They are concerned that 'Pyramus and Thisbe' will not be performed without him. Bottom is known for his generosity, and it is believed that Theseus granted the actors a lifelong pension for their excellent performance of this play. While they lament his absence, suddenly Bottom returns. Their friends want to hear about his story, but Bottom tells them there's no time for that now; they must prepare for the performance. He warns them to avoid onions and garlic to keep their breath sweet for the 'sweet comedy,' which they plan to stage. (English)

0.text: Mr. Weston is a native of Highbury. He met and married Miss Churchill over the objections of her brother, and she died three years later after bearing them a son, Frank. Weston eventually gave Frank up to his wife's brother and his wife, Mr. and Mrs. Churchill, to raise, as they had more money and could support him better, and Frank eventually even took the name Churchill. Mr. Weston purchased a small estate in Highbury. He sees his son every year in London, and everyone in Highbury thinks Frank Churchill is one of their own, and all talk about him with pride even though they have never met him. Now with the marriage of Mr. Weston and Miss Taylor, everyone thinks that he will have to come and visit soon to meet the new Mrs. Weston. Instead Mrs. Weston gets a very nice letter from him that everyone in Highbury approves of and cannot talk about enough

2.text:
Mr. Weston is from Highbury. He married Miss Churchill despite her brother's objections and three years later, he passed away, having given birth to their son, Frank. Later, Mr. and Mrs. Churchill raised Frank, as they had more means and could provide better for him. Frank eventually took on their last name. Mr. Weston bought a small estate in Highbury. He sees his son, Frank, annually in London, and every person in Highbury believes him to be one of their own, taking pride in him, even though they have never met him. With Mr. Weston's marriage to Miss Taylor, it is expected that he will soon come to introduce his new wife, Mrs. Weston. Instead, however, Mrs. Weston writes an appealing letter from him, which everyone in Highbury approves of and praises.

Translation:

Mr. Weston hails from Highbury. He wed Miss Churchill against her brother's opposition and three years later, he perished, having given birth to their son, Frank. Later, Mr. and Mrs. Churchill took Frank in, as they had greater resources and could cater better to his needs. Frank eventually adopted their surname. Mr. Weston acquired a modest property in Highbury. He meets up with his son, Frank, annually in London, and everyone in Highbury considers him as one of their own, taking pride in him, despite never having encountered him. With Mr. Weston's union with Miss Taylor, it is assumed that he will imminently return to present his new spouse, Mrs. Weston. Contrarily, Mrs. Weston pens an alluring letter from him, which everyone in Highbury endorses and commends.

Translation:

Mr. Weston resided in Highbury. Defying the objections of his brother and his three sisters, he wed Mrs. Churchill. Three years following his demise, they dwelt with their nephew Frank in their home and rendered him financially self-sufficient. Over the ensuing years, Frank adopted their surname. Mr. Weston possessed a humble estate in Highbury. Annually, he journeyed to London to pay a visit to his son Frank, and the denizens of Highbury looked forward to his arrival with great anticipation. Whispers spread that Mr. Weston would soon resurface and present Mrs. Taylor to the populace of Highbury. Instead, they were treated to affectionate letters that brought happiness to every household in Highbury.

(It is likely that 'Mrs. Taylor' is the same woman as in the original text.)

0.text: In order to best describe Typee life, the narrator profiles a typical day. Usually, they wake late, after the sun is up. Then they rise and bathe in a nearby refreshing stream. A light breakfast is enjoyed and then pipes are smoked. After breakfast, people tend to whatever they like. Tinor inspects her cloth and food supplies; Marheyo works on his hut; the girls adorn their hair and skin with oils. The narrator usually wanders with Kory-Kory or else sits inside. Then they enjoy a midday nap. Usually in the afternoon, the narrator goes to the Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed in the Ti, it resembles a happy bachelor pad where the best food can be found and where the men sit around smoking and talking. After night falls, a light evening meal of 'poee-poee,' cooked breadfruit, is eaten. Native girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then sleeps. In general, life with the Typees resembles a continual gentle slumber, with activities in between

2.text:
To fully describe the lives of the Tyees, the narrator details a typical day. They usually wake up late, after the sun has risen. Then they stand up and bathe in a nearby cool stream. They enjoy a light breakfast and smoke a pipe after. People do what they want after breakfast. Tinor checks their fabrics and supplies; Marheyo works on his small house; the girls comb their hair and skin. The narrator often goes for a walk with Kory-Kory or stays home. They take a midday nap. In the afternoon, the narrator usually goes to Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed there, it resembles a happy bachelor party, where the best food can be found and men sit and smoke around their pipes. After the night falls, they eat a light dinner of 'poee-poee,' roasted fruit cake. Native girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then goes to bed. Overall, life among the Tyees is similar to a continuous soft slumber, with activities distributed throughout.

Translation:

To fully describe the lives of the Tyees, the narrator outlines a typical day. They usually wake up late, after the sun has risen. Then they stand up and bathe in a nearby cool stream. They enjoy a light breakfast and smoke a pipe after. People do various things after breakfast. Tinor checks their fabrics and supplies; Marheyo works on his small house; the girls comb their hair and skin. The narrator often goes for a walk with Kory-Kory or stays home. They take a midday nap. In the afternoon, the narrator typically goes to Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs assemble. Since women are not permitted there, it resembles a joyful bachelor gathering, where the finest food is available and men sit and smoke around their pipes. After the night has fallen, they eat a light dinner of 'poee-poee,' roasted fruit cake. Native girls frequently dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then retires to their beds. Overall, life among the Tyees is akin to a continuous gentle slumber, with activities interspersed throughout.

4.text: To describe in detail the way of life of the Tyees, the narrator depicts a typical day. They usually wake up late, after the sun has risen. Then they get up and bathe in a nearby cool stream. They enjoy a light breakfast and smoke a pipe afterwards. People do various things after breakfast. Tinor checks their weaves and supplies; Marheyo works on his small house; the girls comb their hair and skin. The narrator often goes for a walk with Kory-Kory or stays at home. They take a midday nap. In the afternoon, the narrator normally goes to Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed there, it resembles a joyful bachelor party, where the best food is found, and men gather around their pipes. After the night has fallen, they eat a light dinner of 'poee-poee,' roasted fruit dessert. Native girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then goes to bed. Overall, life among the Tyees is similar to an uninterrupted soft sleep period, with activities distributed throughout.

0.text: A suspicious Nelly finds out that Cathy has been sneaking away to the Heights during her illness. Nelly forces the truth out of her, and Cathy briefly takes over the narrative. Here's Cathy's story: she goes to the Heights every night while Nelly is sick. She and Linton spend all sorts of time talking and telling stories, finding out how little in common they have. One day, she runs into Hareton, who tries to impress her with the fact that he can now read his own name above the door. She just mocks him and goes into the house. Hareton bursts in and throws a screaming Linton into the kitchen. Linton later blames Cathy for the scene, but they make up. And that's the end of Cathy's narration. Nelly promptly tells Edgar about Cathy's visits to the Heights; again, she is forbidden to go there.

2.text: In English: A suspicious Nelly finds out that Cathy had been secretly visiting the Heights while she was ill. Nelly extracts the truth from her, and Cathy assumes the role of narrator for a while. Here's Cathy's story: Every night, when Nelly is sick, Cathy goes to the Heights. She and Linton spend hours together there, sharing stories and discovering how little they agree. One night, she encounters Hareton, who surprises her by reading his name on the door. She laughs at him and leaves. Hareton bursts in and pushes Linton into the kitchen. Later, Linton accuses Cathy of causing the disturbance, but they make up. This concludes Cathy's story. Nelly shares Cathy's visits to the Heights with Edgar once more; she is no longer allowed to go there.

4.text:
Nelly, growing suspicious, discovered that Cathy had gone to the hill every evening while she was ill. Eventually, Nelly uncovered the reason and Cathy took on the role of the storyteller for a while. Here is Cathy's story: Every evening, while Nelly was ill, Cathy went to the hill. They spent hours together there, telling stories and discovering how little they agreed. One evening, she met Hareton, who surprised her by being able to read his name on the door. She laughed at him and left. Hareton stormed in and forced Linton into the kitchen. Later, Linton accused Cathy of causing the disturbance, but they were just flirting. That is Cathy's story. Nelly shared Cathy's visits to the hill with Edgar again; she was no longer allowed to go there.

0.text: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters visit the Lucas Family the day after the Meryton ball to discuss the events of the previous night. Charlotte Lucas has overheard Bingley remark that Jane is pretty and that he likes her very much. Everyone unanimously approves of Bingley, but they are in disagreement about Darcy. Most of the women criticize his standoffish behavior and haughtiness; but Charlotte defends Darcy by saying that his 'pride' is an inevitable corollary to his position in society as a 'fine young man with a family fortune'. Elizabeth agrees with her partially and says that she could have easily pardoned Darcy's pride if he had not affronted hers. Mary philosophically muses about the distinction between 'pride' and 'vanity'. The chapter also gives a brief account of the Lucas family--Sir William Lucas was a tradesman formerly and was knighted when he was a mayor. He is friendly and courteous. His wife is a kind soul, but too dull. They have many children, the eldest of whom is Charlotte, a sensible, intelligent, and practical girl.

2.text: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters pay a visit to the Lucas family the day following the Meryton ball to recall past events. Charlotte Lucas has discreetly discovered that Bingley is drawn to Jane and enjoys her company. Everyone recognizes Bingley's allure, yet opinions on Darcy differ. Several women condemn his haughty behavior and arrogance; however, Charlotte advocates for Darcy, viewing his 'pride' as an essential trait, even referring to him as 'a handsome young man of substance' within society. Elizabeth concurs to an extent, acknowledging she might have overlooked his pride had he not provoked her. Mary ponders the nuances between 'pride' and 'self-centeredness.' This chapter also offers a brief depiction of the Lucas family. Sir William Lucas was formerly a merchant and was knighted during his tenure as mayor. He is amicable and courteous. His wife is a kind soul, yet dull. They have numerous children, with Charlotte being the eldest - a sensible, intelligent, and practical girl.

0.text: The chapter begins with a description of Mrs. Maylie, the mistress of the house at which Oliver is shot. She is a kindly, old-fashioned elderly woman. Her niece, Miss Rose, is an angelic beauty of seventeen. Mr. Losberne, the eccentric local bachelor surgeon, arrives in a fluster, stating his wonderment at the fact that neither woman is dead of fright at having a burglar in their house. He proceeds to attend to Oliver for a long while. When he returns, he asks the women if they have actually seen the thief. They have not, and, since Giles has enjoyed the commendations for his bravery, he has not told the women that the thief he shot is a small boy. The ladies accompany the surgeon to see the culprit for the first time

(Translation from German to English:
In diesem Kapitel wird Mrs. Maylie, die Herrin des Hauses, in dem Oliver getötet wird, eingeführt. Sie ist eine nette, altmodische alte Dame. Ihre Nichte, Miss Rose, ist siebenzehn und engelhaft. Der einzige Chirurg in der Gegend, Mr. Losberne, ist aufgeregt und überrascht, dass keine Frau wegging, denn es gab einen Dieb unter ihnen. Er hatte lange Oliver beobachtet. Die Damen fragten ihn, ob sie den Dieb wirklich gesehen hatten. Nein, sie hatten ihn nicht gesehen. Mr. Losberne lobte das Mut des Giles und wahrte die Geheimnis der Damen, dass der Mann, den er getötet hatte, tatsächlich eine Frau war. Zum ersten Mal begleiteten die Damen den Chirurgen, um den Verbrecher zu sehen.)

0.text: Fred is foolish enough to go back in search of his old horse, and ends up with an even worse one. He soon becomes ill, and after their regular doctor tries to help and fails, Lydgate is brought in and says he has scarlet fever. Mr. and Mrs. Vincy get angry at their regular doctor, Mr. Wrench, for failing to catch such a serious illness; Mr. Wrench is in turn angry at Lydgate for interfering, and very uncivil to the new doctor. Rumors spread about the confrontation between Mr. Wrench and the Vincys, and between Mr. Wrench and Lydgate. Various opinions and stories surface about the alleged scuffles, leaving everyone worse off as subjects of untrue gossip.

2.text: Fred goes foolishly on his journey to find his old horses and ends up in a worse condition. He will soon be sick, and when Mr. Wrench, their regular doctor, is unable to help, Lydgate is summoned and told that Fred has Scarlett Fever. Mr. and Mrs. Vincy are angry with their regular doctor, Mr. Wrench, for not identifying such a serious illness. Mr. Wrench, in turn, is angry with Lydgate for intervening and is very rude to the new doctor. Rumors of the confrontation between Mr. Wrench and the Vincys, as well as between Mr. Wrench and Lydgate, spread, and various opinions and stories emerge about the supposed fights. Everyone is defamed by the false rumors.

0.text: Ellen decides to run for the doctor, and when she enters the garden, she sees Isabella's dog suspended by a handkerchief and about to die. She releases it and runs on. The doctor asks about Heathcliff, and says that he had heard that he and Isabella had been seen together the night before. This news frightens Ellen, and when she goes into Isabella's room, she finds it empty. She does not want to tell Edgar of it then, as he is busy with Catherine. The doctor tells them to keep Catherine in perfect tranquillity. They all are busy taking care of her, and eventually a maid comes to say that Isabella has run off with Heathcliff. She says that she heard it from another that they were seen together in the middle of the night. Linton says that no one is to go after them as Isabella went of her own accord. He says that they are to talk of her no more, for while he did not disown her, she disowned him

0.text: Fred doesn't get to visit Mary again the next day because he develops a nasty fever overnight. His mother calls their usual surgeon, Mr. Wrench, who prescribes the wrong thing and then doesn't come back to check in on him. So Rosamond recommends that they call Mr. Lydgate , who immediately sees that it's typhoid fever . Lydgate doesn't want to step on any toes or annoy Mr. Wrench, so he tries to be nice about the fact that Wrench totally screwed up. Everyone in Middlemarch finds out about the matter, but they all hear different versions of the story. Some gossip is even getting spread that Lydgate is the illegitimate son of Mr. Bulstrode.

0.text: The action switches to the Earl of Gloucester's castle where Edmund delivers a soliloquy where he appeals to nature to help him undo the laws that inhibit his prospects. He sets in motion his plan to steal Edgar's inheritance and when his father enters, he pretends to be distraught over the contents of a letter he has forged, which he tells his father is from Edgar. The letter urges Edmund to join Edgar in a conspiracy against their father where they would assassinate the Earl and split his estate. Gloucester is easily duped by Edmund's story, which is no doubt partly due to the scenes he has witnessed at King Lear's court. Left alone again, Edmund ridicules his father's stupidity. He is joined by Edgar and warns him that his father is in a rage, suggesting that he should carry a sword in order to protect himself. The reason that Edmund gives to Edgar for his father's rage has a supernatural basis. Edmund's clear skills of persuasion also work on Edgar and he believes the story.

In der Burg der Earls of Gloucester ist Edmund allein, findet Frieden mit der Natur und lasst seine Gedanken in einer Soliloquy laufen, um sein Plan in Bewegung zu setzen, Edgar zu verdrängen. Beim Ankommen seines Vaters zeigt Edmund ihm gefälschte Briefe, die eine Mordverschwörung suggerieren, und schenkt ihm die Erbschaft. Unbemerkt fällt Gloucester in Edmunds Falle, wahrscheinlich beeinflusst durch die Szenen, die er an König Leirs Hof gesehen hat. Allein wieder, verabscheut Edmund die Täuschung seines Vaters. Begleitet von Edgar warnt er ihn von den Gefahren, sich auf ein Schwert für die Selbstverteidigung zu verlassen. Die Quelle von Edmunds Rebellion gegen ihren Vater hat übernatürliche Ursachen. Edgar wird von Edmunds überzeugenden Fähigkeiten überzeugt.

0.text: At the trial the next day, Darnay offers an articulate and well-planned defense of himself. However, the jury remains unconvinced of his innocence until Doctor Alexandre Manette and Mr. Lorry testify on his behalf. The court spectators who called for Darnay's head at the beginning of the trial cheer wildly when the jury votes to free him. As the crowd swarms around Darnay and carries him home, the rapid change in his situation bewilders him. When he reaches home, he embraces Lucie and his daughter, and he and Lucie pray together in thanks. Afterward, Lucie embraces her father, who is proud of what he has accomplished.

In the presence of his wife Lucie and his daughter, he gives thanks with them in prayer. Afterward, he throws himself into the arms of his father, who has taken pride in his actions.

0.text: Cinna the poet is on his way to attend Caesar's funeral when he is accosted by a group of riotous citizens who demand to know who he is and where he is going. He tells them that his name is Cinna and his destination is Caesar's funeral. They mistake him, however, for the conspirator Cinna and move to assault him. He pleads that he is Cinna the poet and not Cinna the conspirator, but they reply that they will kill him anyway because of 'his bad verses.' With Cinna captive, the crowd exits, declaring their intent to burn the houses belonging to Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius.

2.text: At the funeral procession of Caesar, Cinna the poet stands before a violent mob, questioning him about his identity and destination. He replies that he is Cinna and is on his way to Caesar's funeral. However, they mistake him for Cinna the conspirator and prepare to attack. He insists that he is Cinna the poet, not Cinna the conspirator, but they reply that they will still kill him 'because of his bad verses.' After Cinna was seized, the mob departed, announcing their intention to destroy the houses of Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius.

0.text: After one day of being on the 'Henrietta', Fogg takes over as the Captain of the ship after having bribed the entire crew and after locking Andrew Speedy in a cabin. Fogg wished to take the ship to Liverpool. Everything went well for the first few days and then the ship got caught in a gale. The ship has to fight the wind and they lose time as a result. Also since the ship had been traveling on full steam the vessel runs out of coal, as fuel. Fogg nevertheless asks the engineer to run the ship on full steam. He then summons Speedy and pays him enough money to be allowed to burn parts of the ship, in order to use them as fuel. Speedy appreciates the large sum of money and lets Fogg do whatever he wants with the ship. The ship manages to reach Queenstown Harbor and Fogg plans to go to Liverpool from here. They reach Liverpool, and now have only six hours in which to reach England. At this moment, Fix arrests Fogg.

2.text: After a day on board the 'Henrietta', Fogg assumes the captain's role by bribing the entire crew and locking Andrew Speedy in a cabin. His goal was to sail the ship to Liverpool. The voyage began peacefully, but soon they encountered stormy weather. The ship had to give way to the wind, resulting in lost time. In addition, the ship, which had been running on full steam for a long time, had exhausted its coal supply as fuel. Nonetheless, Fogg ordered the engineer to operate the ship at full power. He then summoned Speedy and offered him enough money to burn parts of the ship as fuel. Impressed by the large sum, Speedy agreed to Fogg's demand. The ship arrived at Queenstown Harbor, and Fogg planned to continue to Liverpool from there. Eventually, they made it to Liverpool, leaving them with only six hours to reach England. At this moment, Fix arrested Fogg.

4.text:

The beginning was calm, but they soon had to face the wrath of the weather. The ship had to yield to the wind, resulting in a time loss. Furthermore, the ship, which had been running under full pressure for a long time, had consumed its entire coal supply as fuel. Nevertheless, Fogg ordered the engineer to operate the ship under full pressure. Later, he summoned Speedy and offered him sufficient money to burn parts of the ship as fuel. Overwhelmed by the enormous sum, Speedy acceded to Fogg's demand. The ship reached the harbor of Queenstown, and Fogg planned to depart for England from there. Eventually, they managed to reach Liverpool, which left them only six hours of 'blitzsnellheit' before Fix Fogg arrested them.

I. In the stillness of midnight, I, Mary, sit by Featherstone's bedside, secluded from the intrusions of visitors and the unpleasant encounters of the day. No inheritance expectations clouded my thoughts, and I harbored doubts about Fred's hopes.

III. At three in the morning, the telephone rang, summoning me to Featherstone's side. He implored me to press the lid of his chest and destroy one of his two wills. I balked at the thought of engaging in an indecent act. I demanded that all present be accounted for before my lawyer's arrival.

IV. Featherstone attempted to sway me with monetary incentives. I remained steadfast in my resolve, trying to soothe his agitation. However, his anger and frustration grew. Eventually, he subsided.

V. As the hours passed, I returned to find Featherstone lifeless in his bed.

Translation:

Mary sat by Featherstone's bedside after midnight, away from visitors and the day's unpleasant encounters. She had no inheritance expectations and doubted Fred's hopes.

III. At three in the morning, the telephone rang, summoning Mary to Featherstone's side. He asked her to press the lid of his chest and destroy one of his two wills. She refused, unwilling to participate in an indecent act. She insisted that everyone be present before her lawyer arrived.

IV. Featherstone tried to persuade her with money. Mary remained firm, attempting to calm him down. However, his anger and frustration escalated. Eventually, he calmed.

V. Later, Mary discovered Featherstone lifeless on his bed.

I. At three in the morning, Featherstone's phone rang in Mary's apartment. He asked her to press the lid of his safe and destroy one of his two wills. I didn't want to be a part of such an indecent act. Everyone should be present until my lawyer arrives.

II. Mary sat next to Featherstone's bed past midnight, away from visitors and the unpleasant encounters of the day. I had inheritance expectations and questions about Fred's intentions.

III. At three in the morning, Featherstone's phone rang in Mary's apartment. He asked her to press the lid of his safe and destroy one of his two wills. I didn't want to be a part of such an indecent act. Everyone should be present until my lawyer arrives.

IV. Featherstone tried to bribe me with money. I remained stubborn and tried to calm him down. But his anger and frustration grew. Eventually, he found peace.

V. Later, Mary found Featherstone dead on his bed.

0.text: Now onto the business of summarizing. The author dedicates these idylls to the memory of someone who loved them, speculating that he may find an image of himself in them. This mystery man seems to him just like 'my king's ideal knight,' especially because he followed his conscience above all else and was completely dedicated to one woman. He was faithful to a woman for whom his loss is particularly devastating. Ooh, a clue. Now that he's gone, everyone realizes how great he was. Even though his position on the throne made him especially vulnerable to criticism, he appears blameless. Who could wish for a better life for his only son, or hope for more for his son's sons than that they resemble such an excellent father--Albert the Good? Now the author addresses the widowed queen, telling her to be strong and endure in the memory of the light they two shared. He ends by saying something along the lines of, 'May Albert's love, the love of her children, and the love of her people surround her until God's love reunites her with her husband again.'

2.text:
Now it is a matter of choosing the right words. The author dedicates these idylls to the memory of the one who loved them, probably finding in them his self-image. This enigmatic man seems just as similar to 'my noble ideal knight' to him, above all because he put his conscience above all else and gave himself entirely to a woman. He was faithful to a woman whose loss he deeply felt. Ah, a hint. Now that he is gone, everyone realizes how great he was. Although his position on the throne made him particularly vulnerable to criticism, he appears innocent. Who could hope for better for their only child or wish more for the sons of his child than that they resemble such an exceptional father--Albert the Good? Now the author speaks to the widowed queen and encourages her to remain strong and to remain in the memory of the light that separated her. He concludes with something like, 'Let the love of Albert, the love of his children, and the love of his people surround you, until God reunites you with your husband.' (Note: In this translation, I assumed the target language to be English. If a specific English dialect or variation is intended, please let me know and I will adjust the translation accordingly.)

Now it is a matter of word choice. The author dedicates these idylls to the memory of the one who cherished them, likely finding in them his self-image. This enigmatic man seems just as similar to 'my noble ideal knight' to him, particularly because he placed his conscience above all else and gave himself entirely to a woman. He was faithful to a woman whose loss he grieved deeply. Ah, a hint. Now that he is gone, everyone realizes how great he was. Though his position on the throne made him especially susceptible to criticism, he appears blameless. Who could have hoped for better for their only child or wished more for the sons of his child than that they resemble such an exceptional father--Albert the Good? Now the author addresses the widowed queen and encourages her to remain strong and to remain in the memory of the light that separated her. He concludes with something like, 'Let the love of Albert, the love of his children, and the love of his people protect you, until God reunites you with your husband.'

4.text:
Now it's about the right words. The author dedicates these idylls to the memory of the one who loved them, probably finding himself in them. This mysterious man seems to be the 'ideal noble knight' to the author, particularly because he set his conscience above all else and gave himself entirely to a woman. He was faithful to a woman, whose loss he deeply felt. Ah, a hint. Now that he is gone, everyone realizes how extraordinary he was. Although his position on the throne made him particularly vulnerable to criticism, he appears innocent. Who would have wished for anything better for their only child or more for the sons of their child than that they resembled such an outstanding father--Albert the Good? Now the author speaks to the widowed queen and encourages her to remain strong and stay in the memory of the light that separated her from him. He concludes with something like, 'Let the love of Albert, the love of his children, and the love of his people protect you, until you are reunited with your husband through God.'

German Translation:

Jetzt geht's um die passenden Worte. Der Autor weiht diese Idyllen dem Andenken des, der sie liebte, wahrscheinlich findet er sich in ihnen wieder. Dies geheimnisvolle Mann scheint dem Autor der 'ideale edle Ritter' zu sein, insbesondere weil er sein Gewissen vor allen Dingen setzte und sich ganz einer Frau hingab. Er war treu einer Frau, dessen Verlust er tief empfand. Ah, ein Hinweis. Jetzt dass er fort ist, realisieren alle, wie aussergewöhnlich er gewesen ist. Obwohl seine Stellung auf dem Thron ihn besonders anfällig machte für Kritik, erscheint er unschuldig. Wer hätte besser für das einzige Kind oder mehr für die Söhne seines Kindes gewünscht als dass sie solchen ausragenden Vater ähnelten--Albert dem Guten? 0.text: The Islet David finds himself on a small islet, cut off from the mainland by a small river. He tries to cross the river, but finds it is too wide and deep. He returns to the shore to get his piece of wood, planning to try and float across, but the yard has floated back out to sea. David is now miserable. He begins eating raw shellfish. Sometimes he manages to keep them down, and other times they make him extremely sick. He is especially depressed because he can see a church and several houses on the mainland, but he knows he cannot cross the river. The next day he sees, to his surprise, a red deer, which he realizes must have swum the river. He also discovers that he has lost all his money after the shipwreck. He sees some fisherman, and wildly hails them from the shore. But, to his shock, they only point and laugh at him. The fishermen return later and, in broken English, reveal to him that the river gets very low at low tide. To his surprise and embarrassment, he finds he can practically hop across the river at low tide

2.text:
Suspicion arises in him, as he discovers he can almost leap over the river during low tide.

(Island David lies on a small island, separated from the mainland by a river. He attempts to cross it, but finds it too wide and deep. He returns to the shore to fetch his wooden piece, attempting to swim in the water, but his boat has sailed away into the sea once more. David is sad. He begins to eat raw mussels. Sometimes he manages to keep them, and other times they make him very ill. He is particularly saddened because he can see a church and several houses on the mainland, but he knows he cannot cross the river.

The following day, to his astonishment, he spots a deer, which he supposes had swum across the river. He also learns that his money was lost in the shipwreck. He shouts wildly to some fishermen on the shore. But, to his disappointment, they laugh at him. Later, they return and, in broken English, inform him that the river is very shallow during low tide. To his astonishment and suspicion, he discovers that he can almost jump over the river during low tide.)

4.text:
In English: David suspected something as he discovered he could nearly cross the river during low water.

David was on an island, separated from the mainland by a river. He tried to cross it but found it too wide and deep. He went back to the shore to get his wood piece, tried to swim in the water but his boat was gone again. David was sad. He began to eat raw mussels. Sometimes he could keep them, other times they made him very sick. He was especially disappointed, as he could see a church and several houses on the mainland, but he knew he couldn't cross the river.

The next day, David was surprised to see a deer he thought he had swum across the river. He also learned that his money had been lost in the debris. He shouted angrily at the fishermen on the shore. But to his disappointment, they laughed at him. Later, they returned and informed him that the river was very shallow during low water. To his astonishment and suspicion, he noticed he could nearly cross the river during low water.

0.text: The wanderer. While walking across London, David encounters Mr. Peggotty, who has been to continental Europe in search of Little Em'ly. He shows David letters he has received from Little Em'ly, one expressing guilt at the suffering she has caused Mr. Peggotty and Ham, and two containing money. Mr. Peggotty goes to an inn where he will spend the night before resuming his search

30.text:
Before he had taken it up again and discovered it, it had grown in his life. (English)

Vor dem er es yet again aufgenommen und entdeckt hatte, hatte es in seinem Leben gewachsen. (German)

Explanation:
The original German sentence 'Before er es wieder aufgenommen und entdeckt hatte es in seinem Leben gewachsen' can be translated into English as 'Before he had resumed it and discovered it, it had grown in his life.' The word 'it' in this context refers to a situation or circumstance that had developed in the person's life before they resumed their search and made the discovery.

To preserve the original meaning and context, the German sentence structure must be maintained. The German sentence is in the past perfect tense, which requires the auxiliary verb 'haben' (to have) followed by the past participle of the main verb 'gewachsen' (grown). In English, we can use the past perfect tense with the auxiliary verb 'had' followed by the past participle of the main verb. Therefore, the English translation also uses the past perfect tense to maintain the original meaning and context.

0.text: Three years have passed. Meg has worked and prepared for the wedding; her sisters and mother have enthusiastically helped prepare Dovecote, the little house where Meg and John will take up residence. Mr. March has recovered his health although not his fortune. He seems to spend most of his time absorbed with his books while the women run the household. John has served some time in the war, been wounded and returned home to recover. Since he has not been allowed to return to the army, he takes a job as an underbookkeeper, refusing Mr. Laurence's offers of help. Jo's position with Aunt March is taken over by Amy whom Aunt March bribes with art lessons. Jo continues to write little romances for the paper while secretly working on a novel. Beth has recovered from the fever but has never regained her strength and remains very frail. Laurie has been attending college to please his grandfather. The chapter ends with Jo admonishing Laurie to be serious during the wedding and avoid behaviors that might cause embarrassment or make her laugh. Laurie tries to flirt with Jo, but she will have no part of romantic notions for herself.

Mr. Poyser could barely speak when he was called as a witness, and Mr. Irwine tried to take care of him and accompanied him out of the courthouse. On their first day out, Oliver began to get annoyed because the boys weren't doing anything constructive. Then they spotted a gentleman leaning over a bookstall and Oliver watched as they went up to him. They took a handkerchief out of his pocket and Oliver was horrified that they were stealing from him. The man realized that it was missing and turned to see Oliver running away. The other boys screamed 'stop thief' as the gentleman did and watched as he chased Oliver through the streets.
